item.title: Best, Jason, Neiss, Sherwood, and Jones, Davis. How Crowdfund Investing Helps Solve Three Pressing Socioeconomic Challenges. Crowdfunding PR, Social Media & Marketing Campaigns. Accessed October 21, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper outlines the forces driving the widespread use of crowdfund investing, namely social media, the existence of funding systems that marginalize people outside of major urban centers and the ability of people to function remotely from their work spaces.

item.title: Big Data and the Democratisation of Decisions. The Economist Intelligence Unit, October 2012.
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This report from the Economist Intelligence Unit focuses on the positive impact of big data adoption in the private sector, but its insights can also be applied to the use of big data in governance.

item.title: Big Data, Big Impact: New Possibilities for International Development. Big Data, Big Impact: New Possibilities for International Development | World Economic Forum. Accessed October 17, 2013.
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This report examines the potential for channeling the "flood of data created every day by the interactions of billions of people using computers, GPS devices, cell phones, and medical devices" into "actionable information that can be used to identify needs, provide services, and predict and prevent crises for the benefit of low-income populations."

item.title: Bollier, David. The Promise and Peril of Big Data. The Aspen Institute, Communications and Society Program, 2010.
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This report captures insights from the 2009 Roundtable exploring uses of Big Data within a number of important consumer behavior and policy implication contexts.

item.title: Demystifying Big Data: A Practical Guide to Transforming the Business of Government. TechAmerica Foundations Federal Big Data Commission, 2013.
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This report presents key big data imperatives that government agencies must address, the challenges and the opportunities posed by the growing volume of data and the value Big Data can provide. The discussion touches on the value of big data to businesses and organizational mission, presents case study examples of big data applications, technical underpinnings and public policy applications.

item.title: From Data to Decisions II: Building an Analytics Culture. The Partnership for Public Service and the IBM Center for The Business of Government, October 17, 2012.
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This report discusses strategies for better leveraging data analysis to aid decision-making. The authors argue that, "Organizations that are successful at launching or expanding analytics program...systematically examine their processes and activities to ensure that everything they do clearly connects to what they set out to achieve, and they use that examination to pinpoint weaknesses or areas for improvement.

item.title: Manyika, James, Michael Chui, Brad Brown, Jacques Bughin, Richard Dobbs, Charles Roxburgh, and Angela Hung Byers. Big Data: The Next Frontier for Innovation, Competition, and Productivity | McKinsey & Company. McKinsey & Company, May 2011.
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This report argues that big data "will become a key basis of competition, underpinning new waves of productivity growth, innovation, and consumer surplus, and that "leaders in every sector will have to grapple with the implications of big data."

item.title: Fox, Mark S. Fox City Data: Big, Open and Linked.Working Paper, Enterprise Integration Laboratory (2013).
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper examines concepts that underlie Big City Data using data from multiple cities as examples. It begins by explaining the concepts of Open, Unified, Linked, and Grounded data, which are central to the Semantic Web. Fox then explore Big Data as an extension of Data Analytics, and provide case examples of good data analytics in cities.

item.title: Goldstein, Brett, and Lauren Dyson. Beyond Transparency: Open Data and the Future of Civic Innovation. 1 edition. Code for America Press, 2013.
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This cross-disciplinary survey of the open data landscape features stories from practitioners in the open data space including Michael Flowers, Brett Goldstein, Emer Colmeman and many others discussing what theyve accomplished with open civic data. The book seeks to move beyond the rhetoric of transparency for transparencys sake and towards action and problem solving.

item.title: Granickas, Karolis. Understanding the Impact of Releasing and Re-using Open Government Data. European Public Sector Information Platform, ePSIplatform Topic Report No. 2013/08, (2013).
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper examines the impact of open government data by exploring the latest research in the field, with an eye toward enabling an environment for open data, as well as identifying the benefits of open government data and its political, social, and economic impacts.

item.title: Kassen, Maxat. A promising phenomenon of open data: A case study of the Chicago open data project.Government Information Quarterly (2013).
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper uses the Chicago open data project to explore the empowering potential of an open data phenomenon at the local level as a platform useful for promotion of civic engagement projects and provide a framework for future research and hypothesis testing.

item.title: Keen, Justin, Radu Calinescu, Richard Paige, John Rooksby. Big data + politics = open data: The case of health care data in England. Policy and Internet 5 (2), (2013): 228243.
item.dc:creator: 1l2p

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper examines the assumptions regarding open datasets, technological infrastructure and access, using healthcare systems as a case study.

item.title: Duke, D.J., K.W. Brodlie, D.A. Duce, and I. Herman. Do You See What I Mean? [Data Visualization]. IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications 25, no. 3 (2005): 69
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, the authors argue that a more systematic ontology for data visualization to ensure the successful communication of meaning. "Visualization begins when someone has data that they wish to explore and interpret; the data are encoded as input to a visualization system, which may in its turn interact with other systems to produce a representation. This is communicated back to the user(s), who have to assess this against their goals and knowledge, possibly leading to further cycles of activity. Each phase of this process involves communication between two parties. For this to succeed, those parties must share a common language with an agreed meaning.

item.title: Friendly, Michael. A Brief History of Data Visualization. In Handbook of Data Visualization, 1556. Springer Handbooks Comp.Statistics. Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2008.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, Friendly explores the "deep roots" of modern data visualization. "These roots reach into the histories of the earliest map making and visual depiction, and later into thematic cartography, statistics and statistical graphics, medicine and other fields. Along the way, developments in technologies (printing, reproduction), mathematical theory and practice, and empirical observation and recording enabled the wider use of graphics and new advances in form and content.

item.title: Graves, Alvaro, and James Hendler. Visualization Tools for Open Government Data. In Proceedings of the 14th Annual International Conference on Digital Government Research, 136145. Dg.o 13. New York, NY, USA: ACM, 2013
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Graves, Alvaro, and James Hendler. Visualization Tools for Open Government Data. In Proceedings of the 14th Annual International Conference on Digital Government Research, 136145. Dg.o 13. New York, NY, USA: ACM, 2013.

item.title: Development Index and Its Components. United Nations Development Programme Human Development Reports, September 2010.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Hidalgo, Csar A. Graphical Statistical Methods for the Representation of the Human In this paper for the United Nations Human Development Programme, Hidalgo argues that "graphical statistical methods could be used to help communicate complex data and concepts through universal cognitive channels that are heretofore underused in the development literature."

item.title: Stowers, Genie. The Use of Data Visualization in Government. IBM Center for The Business of Government, Using Technology Series, 2013
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: .This report seeks "to help public sector managers understand one of the more important areas of data analysis today -- data visualization. Data visualizations are more sophisticated, fuller graphic designs than the traditional spreadsheet charts, usually with more than two variables and, typically, incorporating interactive features.

item.title: Budde, Paul. Smart Cities of Tomorrow. In Cities for Smart Environmental and Energy Futures, edited by Stamatina Th. Rassia and Panos M. Pardalos, 920. Energy Systems. Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2014.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper examines the components and strategies involved in the creation of smart cities featuring cohesive and open telecommunication and software architecture.

item.title: Madison, Michael J. Commons at the Intersection of Peer Production, Citizen Science, and Big Data: Galaxy Zoo. In Convening Cultural Commons, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper explores a "case of commons governance grounded in research in modern astronomy. The case, Galaxy Zoo, is a leading example of at least three different contemporary phenomena.

item.title: Benkler, Yochai. The Wealth of Networks: How Social Production Transforms Markets and Freedom. Yale University Press, 2006.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this book, Benkler "describes how patterns of information, knowledge, and cultural production are changing -- and shows that the way information and knowledge are made available can either limit or enlarge the ways people can create and express themselves."

item.title: Brabham, Daren C. Using Crowdsourcing in Government. Collaborating Across Boundaries Series. IBM Center for The Business of Government, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this report, Brabham categorizes government crowdsourcing cases into a "four-part, problem-based typology, encouraging government leaders and public administrators to consider these open problem-solving techniques as a way to engage the public and tackle difficult policy and administrative tasks more effectively and efficiently using online communities.

item.title: Franzoni, Chiara, and Henry Sauermann. Crowd Science: The Organization of Scientific Research in Open Collaborative Projects.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, the authors explore the concept of crowd science, which they define based on two important features: "participation in a project is open to a wide base of potential contributors, and intermediate inputs such as data or problem solving algorithms are made openly available."

item.title: Kittur, Aniket, Ed H. Chi, and Bongwon Suh. Crowdsourcing User Studies with Mechanical Turk. In Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, 453456. CHI 08. New York, NY, USA: ACM, 2008.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, the authors examine "[m]icro-task markets, such as Amazon's Mechanical Turk, [which] offer a potential paradigm for engaging a large number of users for low time and monetary costs. [They] investigate the utility of a micro-task market for collecting user measurements, and discuss design considerations for developing remote micro user evaluation tasks."

item.title: Hernndez-Muoz, Jos M., Jess Bernat Vercher, Luis Muoz, Jos A. Galache, Mirko Presser, Luis A. Hernndez Gmez, and Jan Pettersson. Smart Cities at the Forefront of the Future Internet. In The Future Internet, edited by John Domingue, Alex Galis, Anastasius Gavras, Theodore Zahariadis, Dave Lambert, Frances Cleary, Petros Daras, et al., 447462. Lecture Notes in Computer Science 6656. Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2011
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper explores how the Internet of Things (IoT) and Internet of Services (IoS), can become building blocks to progress towards a unified urban-scale ICT platform transforming a Smart City into an open innovation platform.

item.title: Kitchin, Rob. The Real-Time City? Big Data and Smart Urbanism. SSRN Scholarly Paper. Rochester, NY: Social Science Research Network, July 3, 2013.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper focuses on how cities are being instrumented with digital devices and infrastructure that produce big data which enable real-time analysis of city life, new modes of technocratic urban governance, and a re-imagining of cities.

item.title: Schaffers, Hans, Nicos Komninos, Marc Pallot, Brigitte Trousse, Michael Nilsson, and Alvaro Oliveira. Smart Cities and the Future Internet: Towards Cooperation Frameworks for Open Innovation. In The Future Internet, edited by John Domingue, Alex Galis, Anastasius Gavras, Theodore Zahariadis, Dave Lambert, Frances Cleary, Petros Daras, et al., 431446. Lecture Notes in Computer Science 6656. Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2011.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper explores smart cities as environments of open and user-driven innovation for experimenting and validating Future Internet-enabled services.

item.title: Townsend, Anthony. Smart Cities: Big Data, Civic Hackers, and the Quest for a New Utopia. W. W. Norton & Company, 2013
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this book, Townsend illustrates how cities worldwide are deploying technology to address both the timeless challenges of government and the mounting problems posed by human settlements of previously unimaginable size and complexity.

item.title: Better Choices: Better Deals Report on Progress in the Consumer Empowerment Strategy. Progress Report. Consumer Empowerment Strategy. United Kingdom: Department for Business Innovation & Skills, December 2012.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The report details the progress made through the United Kingdom's consumer empowerment strategy, Better Choices: Better Deals. The plan seeks to mitigate knowledge imbalances through information disclosure programs and targeted nudges.

item.title: Braunstein, Mark L.,. Empowering the Patient. In Health Informatics in the Cloud, 6779. Springer Briefs in Computer Science. Springer New York Heidelberg Dordrecht London, 2013
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: . This book discusses the application of computing to healthcare delivery, public health and community based clinical research.

item.title: Brodi, Elisa. Product-Attribute Information and Product-Use Information: Smart Disclosure and New Policy Implications for Consumers Protection. SSRN Scholarly Paper. Rochester, NY: Social Science Research Network, September 4, 2012.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper from the Research Area of the Bank of Italy's Law and Economics Department "surveys the literature on product use information and analyzes whether and to what extent Italian regulator is trying to ensure consumers awareness as to their use pattern." Rather than focusing on the type of information governments can release to citizens, Brodi proposes that governments require private companies to provide valuable use pattern information to citizens to inform decision-making.

item.title: Report of the Task Force on Smart Disclosure. Task Force on Smart Disclosure: Information and Efficiency in Consumer Markets. Washington, DC: United States Government: Executive Office of the President, May 30, 201
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: National Science and Technology Council. Smart Disclosure and Consumer Decision Making: 3. This inter-agency report is a comprehensive description of smart disclosure approaches being used across the Federal Government. The report not only highlights the importance of making data available to consumers but also to innovators to build better options for consumers.

item.title: Policies in Practice: The Download Capability. Markle Connecting for Health Work Group on Consumer Engagement, August 2010
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This report from the Markle Connecting for Health Work Group on Consumer Engagement -- the creator of the Blue Button system for downloading personal health records -- features a "set of privacy and security practices to help people download their electronic health records.

item.title: Cavoukian, Ann. Personal Data Ecosystem (PDE) - A Privacy by Design Approach to an Individuals Pursuit of Radical Control. Privacy by Design, October 15, 2013
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, Cavoukian describes the Personal Data Ecosystem (PDE), an "emerging landscape of companies and organizations that believe individuals should be in control of their personal data, and make available a growing number of tools and technologies to enable this control." She argues that, "The right to privacy is highly compatible with the notion of PDE because it enables the individual to have a much greater degree of control -- "Radical Control" -- over their personal information than is currently possible today."

item.title: Kirkham, T., S. Winfield, S. Ravet, and S. Kellomaki. 2011. A Personal Data Store for an Internet of Subjects. In 2011 International Conference on Information Society (i-Society), 9297
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper examines various factors involved in the governance of personal data online, and argues for a shift from "current service-oriented applications where often the service provider is in control of the person's data" to a person centric architecture where the user is at the center of personal data control.

item.title: Ohm, Paul. Broken Promises of Privacy: Responding to the Surprising Failure of Anonymization. UCLA Law Review 57, 1701 (2010).
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This article explores the implications of the "astonishing ease" with which scientists have demonstrated the ability to "reidentify" or "deanonmize" supposedly anonymous personal information.

item.title: Polonetsky, Jules and Omer Tene. Privacy in the Age of Big Data: A Time for Big Decisions. Stanford Law Review Online 64 (February 2, 2012): 63.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this article, Tene and Polonetsky argue that, The authors argue that, "The principles of privacy and data protection must be balanced against additional societal values such as public health, national security and law enforcement, environmental protection, and economic efficiency. A coherent framework would be based on a risk matrix, taking into account the value of different uses of data against the potential risks to individual autonomy and privacy.

item.title: Shilton, Katie, Jeff Burke, Deborah Estrin, Ramesh Govindan, Mark Hansen, Jerry Kang, and Min Mun. 2009. Designing the Personal Data Stream: Enabling Participatory Privacy in Mobile Personal Sensing. SSRN Scholarly Paper ID 1999839. Rochester, NY: Social Science Research Network.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This article argues that the Codes of Fair Information Practice, which have served as a model for data privacy for decades, do not take into account a world of distributed data collection, nor the realities of data mining and easy, almost uncontrolled, dissemination.

This report is indicative of the important role in promoting respect for privacy as a fundamental value and a condition for the free flow of personal data across borders played by the OECD for decades. The guidelines revised in 2013 for the first time since being drafted in 1980 are seen as [t]he cornerstone of OECD work on privacy.

item.title: Brner, Katy, Michael Conlon, Jon Corson-Rikert, and Ying Ding. VIVO: A Semantic Approach to Scholarly Networking and Discovery. Synthesis Lectures on the Semantic Web: Theory and Technology 2, no. 1 (October 17, 2012): 1178.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This e-book "provides an introduction to VIVO...a tool for representing information about research and researchers -- their scholarly works, research interests, and organizational relationships."

item.title: Bozzon, Alessandro, Marco Brambilla, Stefano Ceri, Matteo Silvestri, and Giuliano Vesci. Choosing the Right Crowd: Expert Finding in Social Networks. In Proceedings of the 16th International Conference on Extending Database Technology, 637648. EDBT 13. New York, NY, USA: ACM, 2013.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper explores the challenge of selecting experts within the population of social networks by considering the following problem: "given an expertise need (expressed for instance as a natural language query) and a set of social network members, who are the most knowledgeable people for addressing that need?"

item.title: rabham, Daren C. The Myth of Amateur Crowds. Information, Communication & Society 15, no. 3 (2012): 394410.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: . Unlike most of the related literature, this paper focuses on bringing attention to the expertise already being tapped by crowdsourcing efforts rather than determining ways to identify more dormant expertise to improve the results of crowdsourcing.

item.title: Dutton, William H. Networking Distributed Public Expertise: Strategies for Citizen Sourcing Advice to Government. One of a Series of Occasional Papers in Science and Technology Policy, Science and Technology Policy Institute, Institute for Defense Analyses, February 23, 2011
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, a case is made for more structured and well-managed crowdsourcing efforts within government. Specifically, the paper "explains how collaborative networking can be used to harness the distributed expertise of citizens, as distinguished from citizen consultation, which seeks to engage citizens -- each on an equal footing.

item.title: Noveck, Beth Simone. Peer to Patent": Collective Intelligence, Open Review, and Patent Reform. Harvard Journal of Law & Technology 20, no. 1 (Fall 2006): 123162
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This law review article introduces the idea of crowdsourcing expertise to mitigate the challenge of patent processing. Noveck argues that, "access to information is the crux of the patent quality problem. Patent examiners currently make decisions about the grant of a patent that will shape an industry for a twenty-year period on the basis of a limited subset of available information. Examiners may neither consult the public, talk to experts, nor, in many cases, even use the Internet.

item.title: Ober, Josiah. Democracys Wisdom: An Aristotelian Middle Way for Collective Judgment. American Political Science Review 107, no. 01 (2013)
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, Ober argues that, "A satisfactory model of decision-making in an epistemic democracy must respect democratic values, while advancing citizens' interests, by taking account of relevant knowledge about the world."

item.title: Baraniuk, Chris. Power Politechs. New Scientist 218, no. 2923 (June 29, 2013): 3639.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this article, Baraniuk discusses civic hackers,"an army of volunteer coders who are challenging preconceptions about hacking and changing the way your government operates. In a time of plummeting budgets and efficiency drives, those in power have realised they needn't always rely on slow-moving, expensive outsourcing and development to improve public services. Instead, they can consider running a hackathon, at which tech-savvy members of the public come together to create apps and other digital tools that promise to enhance the provision of healthcare, schools or policing."

item.title: Barnett, Brandon, Muki Hansteen Izora, and Jose Sia. Civic Hackathon Challenges Design Principles: Making Data Relevant and Useful for Individuals and Communities. Hack for Change, n.d.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, researchers from Intel Labs offer "guiding principles to support the efforts of local civic hackathon organizers and participants as they seek to design actionable challenges and build useful solutions that will positively benefit their communities."

item.title: Buhrmester, Michael, Tracy Kwang, and Samuel D. Gosling. 2011. Amazons Mechanical Turk A New Source of Inexpensive, Yet High-Quality, Data? Perspectives on Psychological Science 6 (1) (January 1): 35.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This article examines the capability of Amazon's Mechanical Turk to act a source of data for researchers, in addition to its traditional role as a microtasking platform.

item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This article examines issues of data quality in the face of the new phenomenon of geographic information being generated by citizens, in order to examine whether this data can play a role in emergency management.

item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This article describes the way in which "we are harnessing the power of web 2.0 technologies to create new approaches to collecting, mapping, and sharing geocoded data."

item.title: Kanhere, Salil S. 2013. Participatory Sensing: Crowdsourcing Data from Mobile Smartphones in Urban Spaces. In Distributed Computing and Internet Technology, edited by Chittaranjan Hota and Pradip K. Srimani, 1926. Lecture Notes in Computer Science 7753. Springer Berlin Heidelberg.
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper provides a comprehensive overview of participatory sensing a new paradigm for monitoring the urban landscape in which "ordinary citizens can collect multi-modal data streams from the surrounding environment using their mobile devices and share the same using existing communications infrastructure.

item.title: Silvertown, Jonathan. A New Dawn for Citizen Science. Trends in Ecology & Evolution 24, no. 9 (September 2009): 467471
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper explores the tumultuous history of Icelands Crowdsourced Constitution. The since-abandoned document was built upon three principles: distribution of power, transparency and responsibility.

item.title: Gassmann, Oliver, Ellen Enkel, and Henry Chesbrough. The Future of Open Innovation. R&D Management 40, no. 3 (2010): 213221
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper -- an introduction to a special issue on the topic -- Gassmann, Enkel and Chesbrough discuss the evolving trends in open innovation. They define the concept, referencing previous work by Chesbrough et al., as "...the purposive inflows and outflows of knowledge to accelerate internal innovation, and expand the markets for external use of innovation, respectively."

item.title: Citizens as Partners: Information, Consultation and Public Participation in Policy-making. The IT Law Wiki. Accessed October 18, 2013
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This OECD policy report features discussion on the concept of crowdsourcing as a new form or representation and public participation in OECD countries, with the understanding that it creates avenues for citizens to participate in public policy-making within the overall framework of representative democracy.

item.title: Gilman, Hollie Russon. The Participatory Turn: Participatory Budgeting Comes to America. Harvard University, 2012
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this dissertation, Gilman argues that participatory budgeting (PB) produces better outcomes than the status quo budget process in New York, while also transforming how those who participate understand themselves as citizens, constituents, Council members, civil society leaders and community stakeholders.

item.title: Kasdan, Alexa, and Cattell, Lindsay. New Report on NYC Participatory Budgeting. Practical Visionaries. Accessed October 21, 2013
item.dc:creator: asiya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This research and evaluation report is the result of surveys, in-depth interviews and observations collected at key points during the 2011 participatory budgeting (PB) process in New York City, in which "[o]ver 2,000 community members were the ones to propose capital project ideas in neighborhood assemblies and town hall meetings.

item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, the authors take stock of Linked Data's challenges, potential and successes close to a decade after its introduction.

item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This report from the Australia and New Zealand School of Government (ANZSOG) explores the concept of government as a social machine.

item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper examines the components and strategies involved in the creation of smart cities featuring cohesive and open telecommunication and software architecture.

item.title: Hernndez-Muoz, Jos M., Jess Bernat Vercher, Luis Muoz, Jos A. Galache, Mirko Presser, Luis A. Hernndez Gmez, and Jan Pettersson. Smart Cities at the Forefront of the Future Internet.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In The Future Internet, edited by John Domingue, Alex Galis, Anastasius Gavras, Theodore Zahariadis, Dave Lambert, Frances Cleary, Petros Daras, et al., 447462. Lecture Notes in Computer Science 6656. Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2011. This paper explores how the Internet of Things (IoT) and Internet of Services (IoS), can become building blocks to progress towards a unified urban-scale ICT platform transforming a Smart City into an open innovation platform.

item.title: Townsend, Anthony. Smart Cities: Big Data, Civic Hackers, and the Quest for a New Utopia. W. W. Norton & Company, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this book, Townsend illustrates how cities worldwide are deploying technology to address both the timeless challenges of government and the mounting problems posed by human settlements of previously unimaginable size and complexity.

item.title: Kitchin, Rob. The Real-Time City? Big Data and Smart Urbanism. SSRN Scholarly Paper. Rochester, NY: Social Science Research Network, July 3, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper focuses on how cities are being instrumented with digital devices and infrastructure that produce big data which enable real-time analysis of city life, new modes of technocratic urban governance, and a re-imagining of cities.

item.title: Schaffers, Hans, Nicos Komninos, Marc Pallot, Brigitte Trousse, Michael Nilsson, and Alvaro Oliveira. Smart Cities and the Future Internet: Towards Cooperation Frameworks for Open Innovation.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In The Future Internet, edited by John Domingue, Alex Galis, Anastasius Gavras, Theodore Zahariadis, Dave Lambert, Frances Cleary, Petros Daras, et al., 431446. Lecture Notes in Computer Science 6656. Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2011. This paper explores smart cities as environments of open and user-driven innovation for experimenting and validating Future Internet-enabled services.

item.title: Better Choices: Better Deals Report on Progress in the Consumer Empowerment Strategy. Progress Report. Consumer Empowerment Strategy. United Kingdom: Department for Business Innovation & Skills, December 2012.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The report details the progress made through the United Kingdom's consumer empowerment strategy, Better Choices: Better Deals. The plan seeks to mitigate knowledge imbalances through information disclosure programs and targeted nudges.

item.title: Braunstein, Mark L.,. Empowering the Patient. In Health Informatics in the Cloud, 6779. Springer Briefs in Computer Science. Springer New York Heidelberg Dordrecht London, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This book discusses the application of computing to healthcare delivery, public health and community based clinical research.

item.title: Brodi, Elisa. Product-Attribute Information and Product-Use Information: Smart Disclosure and New Policy Implications for Consumers Protection. SSRN Scholarly Paper. Rochester, NY: Social Science Research Network, September 4, 2012.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper from the Research Area of the Bank of Italy's Law and Economics Department "surveys the literature on product use information and analyzes whether and to what extent Italian regulator is trying to ensure consumers awareness as to their use pattern." Rather than focusing on the type of information governments can release to citizens, Brodi proposes that governments require private companies to provide valuable use pattern information to citizens to inform decision-making.

item.title: National Science and Technology Council. Smart Disclosure and Consumer Decision Making: Report of the Task Force on Smart Disclosure. Task Force on Smart Disclosure: Information and Efficiency in Consumer Markets. Washington, DC: United States Government: Executive Office of the President, May 30, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This inter-agency report is a comprehensive description of smart disclosure approaches being used across the Federal Government. The report not only highlights the importance of making data available to consumers but also to innovators to build better options for consumers.

item.title: Policies in Practice: The Download Capability. Markle Connecting for Health Work Group on Consumer Engagement, August 2010.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This report from the Markle Connecting for Health Work Group on Consumer Engagement -- the creator of the Blue Button system for downloading personal health records -- features a "set of privacy and security practices to help people download their electronic health records.

item.title: Benkler, Yochai. The Wealth of Networks: How Social Production Transforms Markets and Freedom. Yale University Press, 2006.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this book, Benkler "describes how patterns of information, knowledge, and cultural production are changing -- and shows that the way information and knowledge are made available can either limit or enlarge the ways people can create and express themselves."

item.title: Brabham, Daren C. Using Crowdsourcing in Government. Collaborating Across Boundaries Series. IBM Center for The Business of Government, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this report, Brabham categorizes government crowdsourcing cases into a "four-part, problem-based typology, encouraging government leaders and public administrators to consider these open problem-solving techniques as a way to engage the public and tackle difficult policy and administrative tasks more effectively and efficiently using online communities."

item.title: Kittur, Aniket, Ed H. Chi, and Bongwon Suh. Crowdsourcing User Studies with Mechanical Turk. In Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, 453456. CHI 08. New York, NY, USA: ACM, 2008.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, the authors examine "[m]icro-task markets, such as Amazon's Mechanical Turk, [which] offer a potential paradigm for engaging a large number of users for low time and monetary costs. [They] investigate the utility of a micro-task market for collecting user measurements, and discuss design considerations for developing remote micro user evaluation tasks."

item.title: Kittur, Aniket, Jeffrey V. Nickerson, Michael S. Bernstein, Elizabeth M. Gerber, Aaron Shaw, John Zimmerman, Matthew Lease, and John J. Horton. The Future of Crowd Work.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, the authors discuss paid crowd work, which "offers remarkable opportunities for improving productivity, social mobility, and the global economy by engaging a geographically distributed workforce to complete complex tasks on demand and at scale."

item.title: Madison, Michael J. Commons at the Intersection of Peer Production, Citizen Science, and Big Data: Galaxy Zoo. In Convening Cultural Commons, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper explores a "case of commons governance grounded in research in modern astronomy. The case, Galaxy Zoo, is a leading example of at least three different contemporary phenomena.

item.title: Aitamurto, Tanja. The Impact of Crowdfunding on Journalism. Journalism Practice 5, no. 4 (2011): 429445.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This article analyzes the impact of crowdfunding on journalism, where "readers' donations accumulate into judgments about the issues that need to be covered."

item.title: Baeck, Peter, and Liam Collins. Working the Crowd: A Short Guide to Crowdfunding and How It Can Work for You. Nesta, May 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Baeck and Collins consider public and social projects to be one of the areas where crowdfunding can have a significant impact. They argue that civic crowdfunding "has the potential to disrupt how money for charitable causes is sourced and how public services and spaces are used and paid for."

item.title: Best, Jason, Neiss, Sherwood, and Jones, Davis. How Crowdfund Investing Helps Solve Three Pressing Socioeconomic Challenges. Crowdfunding PR, Social Media & Marketing Campaigns. Accessed October 21, 2013.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper outlines the forces driving the widespread use of crowdfund investing, namely social media, the existence of funding systems that marginalize people outside of major urban centers and the ability of people to function remotely from their work spaces.

item.title: De Buysere, Kristof, Oliver Gajda, Ronald Kleverlaan, Dan Marom, and Matthias Klaes. A Framework for European Crowdfunding, 2012.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper seeks to provide a "concise overview of the state of crowdfunding in Europe, with the aim of establishing policy and a distinct framework for the European crowdfunding industry," which the authors believe "will aid in the economic recovery of Europe."

item.title: Hollow, Matthew. Crowdfunding and Civic Society in Europe: A Profitable Partnership? Open Citizenship 4, no. 1 (May 20, 2013).
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In this paper, Hollow explores the rise of crowdfunding platforms (CFPs), particularly related to civil society. He notes that, "[f]or civil society activists and others concerned with local welfare issues, the emergence of these new CFPs has been hugely significant: It has opened up a new source of funding when governments and businesses around the world are cutting back on their spending."

item.title: Mollick, Ethan R. The Dynamics of Crowdfunding: An Exploratory Study. Journal of Business Venturing (June 26, 2013).
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper "offers a description of the underlying dynamics of success and failure among crowdfunded ventures," focusing on how personal networks and the project quality and viability have an impact on the success of crowdfunding efforts.

item.title: Stemler, Abbey R. The JOBS Act and Crowdfunding: Harnessing the Powerand Moneyof the Masses. Business Horizons 56, no. 3 (May 2013): 271275.
item.dc:creator: cosmo

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This paper discusses the Jumpstart Our Business Startups (JOBS) Act signed into law by President Obama in 2012, with a specific focus on the CROWDFUND Act, which enables entrepreneurs and small business owners to sell limited equity in their companies to a "crowd" of investors.

item.title: Open Governance Unhangout (7 Dec 2013)
item.dc:creator: 1l2p
item.content:encoded: Join us on 7 Dec 2013, for the first Open Gov Unhangout, an online unconference and conversation with the worlds leading open governance innovators. Watch a short video of their work, and get a chance to talk in small groups (no more than 10 people) about the challenges and opportunities to advance learning into action. How does it work? Unhangout is an unconference that happens online. It's community-based learning instead of top-down information transfer. Think of it as an online workshop with an infinite number of breakout sessions. Each event has a landing page, which we call the lobby. When participants arrive, they can see who else is there and chat with each other. We will set up a number of conversations around topics in the Open Gov Stories series. Participants can propose additional sessions (up to 10 people per session) for in-depth conversations, peer-to-peer learning, and collaboration on projects. Here is more information on how it works in action. We use the unhangout platform that was developed at the MIT Media Lab. It's also an open source project, so you can take the code and run your own events.

item.title: Resources
item.dc:creator: asiya
item.content:encoded:
Performance Measurement and Evidence-Based Management in Practice

The following governmental websites illustrate how multiple levels of government are communicating their performance goals, performance measures, strategies chosen and why (i.e., evidence), and other analyses to the public. These websites are important because they show citizens how their government is managed.  
  • Performance.gov, launched by the Obama Administration in 2011, displays each cabinet departments (and nine other major agencies) mission and lists the agency's strategic goals, objectives, and Priority Goals while providing links to the agencys strategic plan, annual performance plan, and annual performance report and reporting agency progress on government-wide management initiatives and contributions to Cross-Agency Performance (CAP) goals.
  • The MassResults Initiative, which was launched by Massachusetts Governor Patrick as part of his FY14 Budget Recommendation, aims to make state government more effective, more accountable and more open
  • Montgomery County, Massachusetts'CountStat identifies the countys customers and the services the county provides and includes outcome-focused results for those customers. Using data, it gauges both the achievement of the desire results and its efficiency and effectiveness.
  • Virginia Performs shows the Commonwealths performance compared to other states, within Virginia from region to region and allows the user to drill down into their community by exploring regional and locality performance maps. The website also organizes information by agency, providing Planning and Performance pages for each.
  • North Carolina (USA) [Nate, is there a link that you wanted to include with this one?]
  • TheGovernment of Alberta's Annual Reportis the permanent public record of thedollars spent and results achieved by the Government of Alberta for the 2012-13 fiscal year. It consists of two parts: (1) Consolidated Financial Statements, which provide an overall accounting of the governments revenue and spending, and assets and liabilities (2) Measuring Up, which reports on the progress that has been made towards achieving the governments goals. Annual reports for each ministry are also published. See, for example,,the reports for the Alberta Health Services and Albertas Annual Report on Energy.
  • NYC By the Numbers Annual Report, 2013, is anoverview from the Mayors Office of Data Analytics on the state of data-driven government is particularly insightful in its descriptions of the Cities use of both descriptive and predictive analytics.
  • Mayors Management Report.New York, NY (USA)Nate, do you have a brief description for this report?
 

Background Readings on why performance- and evidence-based management is so valuable in government.

Readings in this section explain why performance and evidence-based management is such a powerful means for improving outcomes, return on investment, peoples experience with government, and governments accountability to its citizens and how to do it.
Karen Fenn discusses the Results-Based Accountability in this interview with Mark Friedman. Making Your Work Count on BlogTalkRadio
  • Open Memorandum to Government Executives 'Get Results through Performance Management (2001) from Harvard University's Kennedy School, is a practical guide for state and local managers and executives using performance measures to manage their organizations.
  • Metzenbaum, Shelley H.Performance Accountability: The Five Building Blocks and Six Essential Practices (2006).IBM Center for The Business of Government
  • #DataReads: Stat Programs from the Data-Smart City Solutions at Harvard's Kennedy School overviews city performance measurement and management programs (often referred to as Stat systems) and links to helpful resources for those wanting to learn more.
  • The Bridgespan Groupand American Achieves Results for America's Geek Cities, How Smarter Use of Data and Evidence Can Improve Lives (from Laura Lanzerotti, Jeff Bradach, Stephanie Sud, Henry Bartmeier)is a great background document that discusses performance and evidence-based management as an integrated concept. It focuses on city developments, but the concepts are relevant at all levels of government.
  • Evidence for Policy Design, Harvard University [Nate, can you provide a brief description?]
  • Deliverology: From Idea to Implementation (2010). Michael Barber, Paul Kihn, and Andy Moffit. McKinsey on Government, Spring 2011[Nate, can you provide a brief description?]
  • The Budget of the United States Analytical Perspectives: "Delivering a High Performance Government", chapters 6 and 7. Office of Management and Budget, Executive Office of the President of the United States
 

Background Readings on Performance- and Evidence-Based Management Concepts in Non-Profits

  • The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation Annual Letters, 2013 & 2014
  • Leap of Reason Managing to Outcomes in an Era of Scarcity. The Morino Institute
  • Working Hard & Working Well A Practical Guide to Performance Management. Dr. David E.K. Hunter. The Morino Institute
 

Background Readings on Performance and Evidence-Based Management Concepts in Business

  Collins, Jim. Good to Great. Fast Company. October 2001
 

Case Studies

  • Dennis C. Smith and William J. Bratton. Performance Management in New York City: Compstat and the Revolution in Police Management. Quicker, Better, Cheaper? Managing Performance in American Government. 2001
  • Insert: Kennedy School CompStat case study
  • Vision and Strategy: Paul H. ONeill at OMB & Alcoa . Kennedy School of Government Case Program, C16-92-1134.0. 2002.
 
 

Research

University of Wisconsin ProfessorDonaldMoynihanestablished the Performance Information Project (PIP) to aggregate contemporary empirical research on how performance data are used in public services. The primary goals of PIP are to facilitate an international network of scholars interested in advancing knowledge on performance information use, and inform practitioners who are seeking to foster data-driven management.
  • Performance Information Project. Robert M. La Follette School of Public Affairs. University of Wisconsin-Madison

item.title: Primer
item.dc:creator: asiya
item.content:encoded:
Why should governments use performance and evidence-based management?

[DRAFT, insert images] Effective measurement & management are key contributors to government success. Setting ambitious goals that mean something to the public, measuring progress on these goals frequently, and using and communicating performance data to find smarter ways to deliver is good for government and good for the people it serves, leading to better outcomes in the places where government touches our everyday lives. What is government performance management and why is it important? When we talk about performance management, we are referring to governments use of goals, measurement, analysis, and evaluation to increase the positive impact of government action on the quality of peoples lives, experience with government, and governments return on investment. A broad body of evidence and experience suggest that well-chosen goals and measurement are among the most powerful change-driving mechanisms available to government leaders. This is true whether embraced by the leaders at the highest levels of government, or at other levels of leadership. Elected chief executives such as Presidents and Prime Ministers, heads of sub-national states and provinces, and city and regional leaders have all demonstrated the remarkable change-driving power of goals and measurements when certain conditions are met Heads of field offices, individuals seeking to galvanize progress by a single office on specific problems, and those (including front-line entrepreneurs) seeking to make progress on problems requiring attention from multiple programs or organizations have similarly tapped into the power of goals and measurement. But even when measurements are collected, they are of limited value if not used on a regular basis to inform action. While it may seem too obvious to say, to be useful, goals and measurements cannot just be reported in mandated performance reports; they must be used. Legal mandates to set goals and report performance at the federal and state level in the United States and abroad have often, in the past, resulted in wasteful practices. To have value, goals need to be communicated, progress toward them needs to be measured, and performance and other data need to be analyzed and discussed to find what works, what doesnt, and why. Further, the person(s) responsible for managing progress on the goal needs to be clearly identified, and that person needs to engage others responsible for and with the potential to contribute to improvement to find and adopt better practices. How should goals and measurement be used? Goals should be used to communicate clearly and succinctly across an organization, to oversight bodies, to delivery partners, and to other stakeholders what an organization hopes to accomplish with its available or proposed resources and authorities. For claritys sake, leaders should communicate which of their organizational goals are priority goals. A robust body of research finds that specific, ambitious targets that are quantity and time-specificanreasonable relative to available resources inspire, energize, and stimulate innovation. Therefore, leaders should set stretch targets in areas they consider a priority,essentiallypriority goals. Specific (and perhaps less ambitious) targets can be helpful in other areas, as well, for clarifying what an organization wants to accomplish and what it is will not focus on at the moment. Within an organization, goals should be used to align parts of an organization with efforts of other parts and with leadership priorities. They should similarly be used to coordinate efforts with delivery partners, such as state and local governments. Goals can be used to invite conversation about the clarity of a goal (and coherence relative to other organizational goals) so they can be refined to be more understandable and specific, if necessary. Goals can also be used to facilitate discussions with delivery partner first to pinpoint areas of agreement and disagreement that might need resolution and then to sort out who needs to do what by when. The clear articulation of goals can similarly stimulate healthy discussion with oversight bodies and the public. Measurements should be used for multiple purposes. This includes identifying problems needing attention and their characteristics (e.g., prevalence, pattern similarities and variations, relationships andoutliers) to inform priority-setting and treatment design. It includes measurement to find positiveoutliers possiblyassociated withbetterpractices being used in some location or time periods, which can be used to trigger tests of whether those practices, replicated elsewhere, result in superior performance. It includes measurement to determine if efforts to accelerate adoption ofbetterpractices are happening, and if the impacts are as expected. It also includes measurement to detect (and prevent) unwanted side effects, give early warnings, find root causes, etc. Once goals are set, they should be complemented by designation of individuals to lead progress on each goal (goal leaders), frequent measurement of progress, data-rich discussions with people in the organization and potential delivery partners withpotentialto contribute to the goal to identify what seems to be working and what needs attention. This not only aligns organizational efforts with the statedgoals butalso tends to speed progress on them. Of course, an organization needs to consider its goals in the context of its available resources, including funds but also skills. Caution needs to be exercised when using goals and measurement, however, because they can backfire. Requirements to set goals and measure performance can impede progress if emphasis is placed on measuring percentage of targets met rather than whether performance is trending in the right direction at a healthy pace. Misdirected emphasis diverts energy and intelligence away from finding ways to improve to setting targets that will be easy to meet, which in turn tends to curb peoples inspiration and inclination to innovate, and, in some cases, manipulating measurements.   [will update with slideshow once images are available]

Shaun Donavan, Secretary, Department of HUD

"When I was working for Former Mayor Bloomberg in New York City, he helped us put together a housing plan with a very clear target: 165,000 unit in 10 years... It created real alignment with our partners outside of government, as well as within City Hall. Everybody knew what we were focused on and wanted to be held accountable to, and our partners rallied around that goal."

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: 1l2p
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like pia coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Join the Open Knowledge Foundations Data team
Learn more about and participate in Project Open Data

Go on data.gov or any open data set you're interested in and figure out what are the more popular data sets in different cities and countries.What trends do you notice? Which data sets are most compelling to you?

Learn more about and participate in Project Open Data, an online collection of code, best practices, and case studies developed to help agencies adopt the framework presented in the OMB memorandum M-13-13Open Data Policy-Managing Information as an Asset.
Join the Open Knowledge Foundations Data team and help to prepare and load data into OpenSpending and to support community members with data-related issues
Dive into different learning projects with the Open Data Institute.

The World Bank's Open Data initiative is intended to provide all users with access to World Bank data. The data catalog is a listing of available World Bank datasets, including databases, pre-formatted tables, reports, and other resources.

Explore Socrata, a software company that helps public sector organizations improve transparency, citizen service and fact-based decision-making by efficiently delivering data to citizens, employees and developers in a user-friendly experience on web, mobile and machine-to-machine interfaces.

Explore the Lehman Community Connect Bronx Information Portal. The new experimental Lehman College community website provides a map-based platform to easily find, view and interact with publicly available data.

Explore the Lehman Community Connect Bronx Information Portal

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: W3C (World Wide Web Consorcium) list of case studies around linked data

RDF is a directed, labeled graph data format for representing information in the Web. This specification defines the syntax and semantics of the SPARQL query language for RDF. SPARQL can be used to express queries across diverse data sources, whether the data is stored natively as RDF or viewed as RDF via middleware.
Euclid-project funded by the EU, which serves as an Academy around Linked Data

What is Linked Data? The Semantic Web is a Web of Data of dates and titles and part numbers and chemical properties and any other data one might conceive of. The collection of Semantic Web technologies (RDF, OWL, SKOS, SPARQL, etc.) provides an environment where application can query that data, draw inferences using vocabularies, etc.

The network of scientists will facilitate scholarly discovery. Institutions will participate in the network by installing VIVO, or by providing semantic web-compliant data to the network. Vivo relies on semantic-compliant web data in order to build its database.

item.title: Get Involved
item.dc:creator: 1l2p
item.content:encoded:
The Academy is looking for collaborators. We are looking for people and organizations to build the Academy with us. If you have documents that should be listed here, are hosting a workshop we could help promote, or have a story to share - please get in touch. Let's collaborate! Channel Partners Channel partners act as stewards for a content area of the Academy. They create courses and other learning activities, offer mentorship, and curate a set of readings, videos, and podcasts.We take care of the rest - we work with you to get your materials on the site, help you design learning activities that engage users, offer technology and hosting. If you are interested in working with us as a channel partner, please get in touch via this form. Add a resource (What's missing?) You have an open governance case-study to add, a report to share, or a video to contribute. We'll help you tell your story and connect with a broader audience. Leave a comment below and we'll get in touch. Follow the conversation (GovLab Twitter lists) Our curated Twitter lists are a great way to monitor important developments and conversations.The fullOpen Governancelist includes over 150 must-follow accounts from across sectors and discipline areas. Twitter users can follow the full list and/or keep tabs on important players working within the GovLabs three core lines of inquiry, or "levers of open":Smarter Governance Getting Expertise In/Open Data Governance Pushing Data Out/Devolved Governance Sharing Responsibility. Additional lists for specific disciplines or interest area:
  • General Open Governance,
  • Legal and Policy Barriers to Open Governance,
  • Technology,
  • Innovation,
  • Policy,
  • Business and Economics,
  • Behavioral Science and Social Psychology.
Twitter users can subscribe to theGovLabs Network of Collaboratorslist, featuring individuals working directly with the GovLab to improve peoples lives by changing how we govern. Learn with Gov 3.0. Even if you are not officially enrolled in the Gov 3.0. online program, you can still follow along and learn at your own pace. For example: - We encourage you to participate by utilizing the a la carte resources on thegovlabacademy.org. - You can use the syllabus to guide your own learning. - We will be recording all the lectures of the program and uploading them on the site for public access. *Please check back to the Gov 3.0. webpage soon to learn about news, updates, further opportunities for involvement, and new developments as GovLab Academy grows and evolves! The GovLab's Open Governance Knowledge Base The Open Governance Knowledge Base is a collaborative, wiki-style repository of information and research at the nexus of technology, governance and citizenship. We encourage you to learn from and contribute more resources to this repository. Did we forget someone?Please help us out, tweet their details @TheGovLab or leave a comment below.

To suggest more readings for our list, please email biblio@thegovlab.org

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: 1l2p
item.content:encoded:
Join a community of people who want to make real change happen.

About The GovLab Academy:

Today most organizations, especially government, work behind closed doors.If we believe that working together in diverse groups we can tackle the problems we cannot solve alone, we have to learn new habits: how to work openly and participate effectively.Funded by The John S. and James L. Knight Foundation,The GovLab Academyprepares future public interest leaders with the mindset and skillset to leverage technology for improved decision making, builds the capacity to solve public problems through open innovation and collaboration and trains successful future leaders in government, not- and for-profit companies, and networks.
The GovLab Academy aims to apply the principles of innovation to education byunbundling knowledge access to a la carte content, tools and instructors; bundled knowledge content organized by expert-instructors to jumpstart learning; and providing mentorship, fellowship and feedback to enable mastery.

A partnership between The GovLab and MIT Media Labs Online Learning Initiative, we offer:

  • The GovLab Academy Platform - An unbundled online platform with an evolving set of content, modules and instructors on innovations in governance includingcurated videos, podcasts, readings and activities designed to enable the purpose driven learner to deepen his or her practical knowledge at her own pace.The site features both curated content drawn from a variety of sources and original interviews with innovators from government, civil society, the tech industry, the arts and academia talking about their work around the world implementing innovations in practice, what worked and what didnt, to improve real peoples lives.Future releases of the site will include using behavioral economics and randomized control trials, prizes and citizen science for policymaking. The Academy is soliciting participation by policy entrepreneurs, technologists, civil society activists, academics and artists willing to mentor participants in using these and other innovations to solve concrete problems;
  • Gov 3.0: A first bundled mentoring and training program (14-week program) to help people in their own communities become more effective problem solvers.
  • The GovLab Academy Fellowship: A fellowship opportunity to support Gov 3.0 graduates to carry their ideas through to completion and gain mastery.
We believe that by learning to work together in diverse groups, work openly, and participate effectively, we can tackle the problems we cannot solve alone.

About The GovLab:

The Governance Lab (The GovLab) at New York University strives to improve peoples lives by changing how we govern. We endeavor to strengthen the ability of people and institutions to work together to solve problems, make decisions, resolve conflict and govern themselves more effectively and legitimately. We design technology, policy and strategies for fostering more open and collaborative approaches to governance and we test what works. Founded in 2012, with funding from the MacArthur and Knight Foundations, The GovLab brings together thinkers and doers who design, implement, and study technology-enabled solutions that advance a collaborative, networked approached to reinvent institutions of governance.

item.title: Public Mapping Mission
item.dc:creator: 1l2p
item.content:encoded:
Aerial photography at the intersection of open science and public policy

Overview

The Public Mapping Mission is an online-offline hybrid course in open science and public policy. Developed in collaboration with The GovLab Academy, Public Lab, The Center for Urban

Science and Progress, and Peer-to-Peer University, the two-part course is composed first of an online seminar with a panel of speakers, followed by a hands-on activity mapping a local community using a balloon mapping kit. This combination of both an online course and offline put into practice activity provided a unique opportunity to not only talk and learn about a specific issue, but to also participate in that issue through a hands-on activity.

Part 1: Online Seminar

The first online session took place on November 22, 2013 and was comprised of three presentations surrounding the topics of open science and public policy. Hosted on a unhangout platform built by our partners at P2PU and MIT Media Lab, these presentations were meant to provide context and understanding around the broader topic and offer participants an understanding of how these topics are taking shape in the world. Following the presentations, participants had an opportunity to ask questions directly to the presenters.

The presenters included:

  • Beth Noveck who spoke about the impact citizen science has on public policy and the growing trends in this participation as well as the increasing acceptance of this participation by governing bodies.

  • Francois Grey who spoke about the evolution of science and the variety of opportunities for citizen involvement with the development of the internet and low-cost technologies.

  • Jeffrey Warren, co-founder of the Public Lab, spoke about the Public Lab and their experiences working within the scope of citizen science. Jeffrey particularly spoke about the importance of community when pursuing citizen science as well as what makes the Public Lab approach to science so unique.

The video recording of the seminar is located here. You can access the full transcription is here.

Part 2: Hands - On Practice

The second part of the course focused on the tools and techniques used by citizen scientists that could be put into practice. The day began with a balloon mapping workshop conducted by Nicholas Johnson which was held online December 7th. This workshop gave an in-depth explanation on how to prepare and execute balloon photography. Immediately following the online workshop, participants were encouraged to travel into their communities to put into practice what was learned. The how-cast video is located here.

In New York City, a group was organized to map Newtown Creek, an industrial waterway between northern Brooklyn and southern Queens. The event was also joined by members of the North Brooklyn Boating Club who offered canoes to allow an on-the-creek mapping opportunity. The mapping of Newtown Creek offline event included ten participants who braved the frigid weather to participate in the event. Read more about the event on this link to the Public Lab research note written by Nicholas Johnson. Photos from the event are located here.

Stay in touch:

  • Join thePublicLab community and discussion through their mailing listshttp://publiclab.org/wiki/mailing-lists

item.title: Academy Accelerator: Solving Public Problems with Technology
item.dc:creator: luisdaniel12
item.content:encoded:
We are training a new generation of public entrepreneurs and change agents to tap the intelligence of citizens and leverage the resources of institutions to create actionable projects that improve peoples lives.

About the Academy Accelerator Program

The project Accelerator is a unique offering from the GovLab Academy. Each phase of this program will help you steer your civic innovation project through each step of an agile, design-driven development process. You will learn how to:
  • Sharply define your problem
  • Map the solution space and the current state of practice
  • Apply human-centered design to understand the desired user experience
  • Create prototypes and mock-ups
  • Pitch your project to external audiences and build support
The program is focused on helping you to translate this learning into an implementable project that you can take forward in the real world as an Academy Accelerator graduate.

Who is it for?

You do not need to be enrolled in an academic institution to apply to the Accelerator, and we offer flexible formats that are compatible with work or study. The program is for you if:
  • You are purpose-driven learner with an idea that has potential to improve the lives of citizens
  • You are an innovator working inside, outside, or in collaboration with established institutions
  • You are looking for the tools, resources, networks and support you need to take your civic innovation project from idea to implementation

How does it work?

We have already tested versions of this program with over a hundred participants from graduate schools, government and civil society. Starting now, you can apply to take part in one of two different formats of the Academy Accelerator program: Extended Format
  • Beginning in September 2014 we will offer extended versions of the Accelerator in partnership with several academic institutions. The program will be aligned with the academic timetable (approximately 12 weeks) and will be open to learners from multiple disciplines as well as to online participants.
Intensive Format
  • Starting in Fall 2014 we will offer shorter, more intensive versions of the Accelerator program aimed at professional learners inside (public sector employees) and outside of established institutions (social innovators).
You can signal your interest in these two different programsusing the form below. We may ask for a more in-depth project proposal at a later date. There is no fee for the program.

What do I get?

The program will be structured around online master classes, lectures, exercises, and presentations that lead you through the stages of project development. The programming will be interactive and you will receive feedback on your project materials and pitches.
  • We will identify your learning needs and direct you to the most relevant resources on civic innovation - videos, literature and interviews - across a range of themes (for example, open data, big data, crowdsourcing etc). These materials are hosted on the Academys online platform developed in collaboration with the Program on Online Learning at the MIT Media Lab.
  • At every step, you will benefit from ongoing mentoring from experts and also have access to support from the wider Academy community of peers and practitioners
  • At the end of the program, you will have created the collateral materials essential to the success of your project (among them, memos, blogs, slide decks, and videos) and built the necessary prototypes and mockups to test your idea with real users
As an alumnus or alumna, you will receive an online badge recognizing your achievements (the badge will be Mozilla-friendly, transportable and stackable). You will continue to have access to an online community of peers and experts
