item.title: Joonas Pekkanen on Using Crowdsourcing to Craft Legislation
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Joonas Pekkanenis the Chairman ofAvoin Ministeri, or Open Ministry, a non-profit organization based in Helsinki, Finland which facilitates the crowdsourcing of legislation.

In this HowCast, you will learn:

  • The Motivation behind crowd-crafting legislation in Finland
  • Examples of topics from the Finish crowd has taken up
  • Lessons learned from this process

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more aboutAvoin Ministeri:http://avoinministerio.fi.
  • Open Ministry Blog (English):http://openministry.info
  • Explore the code behind crowd-crafting legislation:Avoin Ministeri on GitHub:https://github.com/avoinministerio/avoinministerio
  • Check out the Gov Lab Academy Toolkit on Crowdsourcing Opinions & Ideas.
  • Watch the Open Government Partnership Webinar on E-Petitions
  • Read the Open Government Partnerships case study about Croatias implementation of a Public Consultation Code to ensure more inclusive and meaningful consultation on laws.
  • Hit the books: "Crowdsourcing for Democracy: New Era In PolicyMaking" by TanjaAitamurto. Publications of the Committee for the Future, Parliament of Finland. January 2012.

Transcript:

The Idea Behind Citizen-crafted Legislation .I founded the CSO called the Open Ministry, which is about crowdsourcing legislation and putting well-prepared law proposals in front of the parliament in Finland. The backdrop is that in Finland there was a constitutional amendment in 2012 where now 50,000 people or 1.3% of the voting population, if they support a proposal, the parliament has to process it in the same fashion as it does the government bills. Our aim is especially to make sure that anybody who wants to make such a proposal to the parliament has all the lessons learned and all the resources that have been amassed in the earlier campaigns so that they can make the best of the new institution. The idea is not to get the overall public opinion but rather to see if certain topics rise from the discussion. There was in some cases even consensus between conflicting interests.

Crowdcrafting Off-Road Traffic Law.There was a pilot that collected crowdsourcing tools to collect different questions and then the answers regarding what the off-road traffic law should be like in Finland. That got a number of different interest groups involved in the discussion on how to regulate and compensate for damages and so on. It's all terrain vehicles in the north, the snow mobiles and so on. And then theres interests of the indigenous people in the north of Finland and hard to compensate for the landowners.

The committee agreed with the ministry of environment who's in charge of the off-road traffic regulation. They agreed on doing this pilot where they set a webpage for collecting the questions and answers to problems and solutions regarding the regulation and other issues around the off-road traffic law and how the landowners should be compensated and how that nature should be taken into consideration. The off-road traffic law was considered outdated and the previous parliament didnt have time to update the law. It was foreseen that it would interest many of the people who are affected by the law. They used an online platform, an existing platform, that was modified for this use case. They had different phases of inputting first and then brainstorming and then framing the questions and finding the solutions together with them. There's a lot of facilitation obviously involved in carrying out such a crowdsourcing effort. The politicians and the civil servants preparing the law need to understand that it's not a representative sample of the population obviously because people chose to participate and people with their own interests, personal interests of course were vocal about their needs and requirements for the law.

The Importance of Listening to Public Opinion.The ideas arent always something that can be implemented but they always need to be addressed and it needs to be explained why certain things that rise from the participation can't be implemented or are conflicting with other interests and have to be left out of the bill. Just ignoring them and not explaining why they are left out of the process, that's something that needs to be sure that doesnt happen. I think there's good motivation by the public officials. They want to hear what the public has to say. They want to participate citizens but I think it's a learning process now through these pilots that both sides learn how to take that input and actually have that influence what happens. The important thing to keep in mind is that if people participate and they dont get feedback or they're ignored, they will quickly lose interest. The processes have to be such that when citizens are participating, they get the explanation of why certain things, for example, are left out of the preparation. When people sign up for these online engagement tools, they should be the primary channel to get the feedback back to them once the process goes further and the actual law proposals are being drafted. There needs to be feedback back to the original participant in the discussion. Learning From Pilot Programs.I think in the future, there needs to be more pilots to learn from because each is a bit different. Different people will choose to participate on different topics. To get more people involved, to get not only the people who have their own personal interest that motivate their participation, that's important. Obviously those people have the motivation to take part. The challenge is to get regular people who are not motivated by personal interest to get involved. That's the big issue. That's the big question to answer in the future I think.My hopes are that in the future, in the very near future, governments will take the citizen participation, citizen empowerment seriously and regular people will consider these new ways of influencing something that they can do in addition to voting every 4 years or so.

item.title: Giorgi Kidiashvili on Collecting Data to Hold Government Accountable in Georgia
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Giorgi Kidiashviliis the Director of Institute for Development of Freedom of Information (IDFI) in Georgia. In 2010, IDFI collaborated with the Open Society Georgia Foundation to create Georgias public information database, opendata.ge.

In this HowCast, you will learn:

  • The process of projects implementation
  • Challenges and lessons learned
  • The gains IDFI have made promoting proactive disclosure of data

Additional Resources:

    • Learn more about opendata.ge:
      • Georgia Public Information Database: http://www.opendata.ge
      • IDFI Website: http://www.idfi.ge
      • Open Society Georgia Foundation: http://www.osgf.ge
    • Explore the Gov Lab Academy toolkit on Open Data.

Transcript:

Making Public Information Accessible The name of the project was Public Information Database, www.opendata.ge. The purpose of the project was to collect public information that was kept by the government and made it accessible to the public online. It was a joint idea of the Open Society Georgia Foundation team and our organization. The idea initially was to create this website and to promote peoples participation in control over the government. The main goal of the project was to collect information kept by the government. We requested information, received responses, scanned this information, created a special website called opendata.ge and we uploaded this information on the website. The idea was that the government was not proactively publishing information and we did it instead of them. The idea was to give opportunity to people to see information that they couldnt request themselves. They could, potentially, but as to the lack of the tradition of peoples control, the citizens control over the government, we tried to promote this work.

Project Implementation.Initially it was not planned to be developed that much. It was a just very short six-month project to create this website. We didnt plan to have any additional funding to develop the project. It was so successful because access to information was quite limited. There was very limited information, government information, especially about government institution spendings that as soon as we published this information there was a big reaction from the public. We got additional funding for one-year project and it was aimed to cover those organizations which were outside ministries like legal entities of public law under agencies of ministries, and then it was extended again. Today we are covering all government institutions, up to 250. What is the most important, we are publishing annual rankings of those organizations who are showing the best access to information practice and those who are not showing the best access to information practice. We have special awards to those who are best in access to information and for those who show the worst example of access to information in my country.

Learning from Challenges.We requested information from all the ministries but just very few responded to this, but those who were responded got the worst reaction. We tried to explain to people that those who didnt responded, they have to hide something which is worse than this that these guys, ministries Im talking and deputy ministers got the bonuses. This reaction was because this information was not open before. This led to the additional steps to request more information, to involve citizens in access to information practice, and this was why the project was extended.

Promoting proactive disclosure.When we started monitoring access to information in Georgia, the percentage of responses were only 40%. In three years it raised up to 95. We had the plan to promote and provoke government to lead to proactive disclosure of information and it was done. After three years of the project in 2012, we had finally legislative changes related to proactive disclosure of information. Freedom of information legislation was demanded and We participated in it. We took just very active part in drafting this new amendment, leading to proactive disclosure of information. Now, starting from 2013, government institutions are obliged to publish information. This is mostly the information that we were requesting from them. Those categories I was talking about from the opendata.ge project, information related to expenses, related to information about [inaudible] that government is passing. This information including budget transparency, projects that the government institutions are providing, will be mandatory for government institutions to proactively publish on their website. So this is already a very big achievement.

item.title: Ania Caldern on Gathering Citizen Input on Digital Strategy
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Ania Caldernis the General Director of National Digital Strategy Coordination for the Office of the President of Mexico.

In this HowCast, you will learn:

  • The steps Ania and her team took in establishing the country's open data platform
  • How they gathered citizen input on the types of data Mexicans wanted see published.

Additional Resources:

  • Explore the "datatron":http://datos.gob.mx/
  • Check out the Gov Lab Academy Toolkit on Open Data.
  • Watch the Open Government Partnership webinar on "Strengthening demand for and Use of Open Government Data Initiatives", featuringJennifer Shkabatur from the World Bank andJay Bhalla of Code 4 Kenya.
  • Explore the code behind the datatron on Datos.gob.mx GitHub account.

Transcript:

Establishing an Open Platform with Open Data.I work at the Office of the President in Mexico. I work in the coordination of national digital strategy and I lead the area of digital innovation. We're very excited because we're creating the national policy on open data. It's our open data initiative. Initially we've worked with the team of statisticians, data scientists, policy makers, and designers to come up with what we call the Datatron. This is a specifically an open platform, it's an ad infinitem randomize polling system that can help us understand what users, what type of data users are more interested in, and in that way help us classify and prioritize the type of data that well be releasing and also designing mechanisms for this data to be used towards really specific causes that users are most interested in.

Moving Beyond Releasing Datasets.We're trying to focus not only on releasing massive sets of data, but also on empowering communities, and identifying them to be able to work together to solve issues that can have a social impact or even economic growth. It's been interesting process because it's been five days since we've launched this site; it's in a beta process so far. It is datos.gov.mx. Already there's been discussions spurring around this, on specific media, blogs and channels. I think it's been really useful, because it's starting a conversation around the national policy on open data in Mexico. It's raising expectation as well, which is great for us because it can also become an accountability mechanism for us to be able to implement.

Gathering Citizen Input.The first approach was to think of a way that we can get more people participating from the beginning even before we launch our open data website.This polling system was a very simple way to get users involved in whatever way they wanted to. Those that are most heavy users will go further into the process. It was a very organic process; it's an experiment for us as well. So far we have received close to 40,000 different results...votes around the system. We have so far identified 500 different data sets. Of course it's hard for people to go into them all, but It's a random process, we hope with the massive use of different citizens selecting them will get a clearer picture of what type of information can be most useful and valuable toward citizens. We're looking at open data in terms of two specific approaches: One would be trying to identify the demand from the user side. We've also identified a very specific demand within government itself. Our second method for prioritizing the data we're releasing has been around several interviews with key champions within different agencies that we've had the opportunity to work with to figure out what type of programs and that are linked towards to national objectives where we can hopefully find data that can make them implement the programs in a better and more efficient way.

The Value of a Participatory Process.With this project, our hope is to get communities to make government more responsible, to what they're looking for. For us and our responsibility is to develop the open data initiative from the office of the President. This is also a great way to use it as a tool, to show people inside of government what citizens are looking for. It's not us, the government, saying this is what you have to open up. It's a more open and participatory process from the beginning. This process requires multi-stake approach and once you get right people involved, passionate communities, experts around different topics, all around data, you can have and create insights that beforehand couldnt have been possible. I think we also need to approach this to a storytelling angle which is why I think this type of projects are great. It's hard to measure the types of results that this will happen, and there's different levels and I think there's a big challenge for us in bringing this to a local level where it can be closer to users needs. For people to actually realize it, this is useful for them. Partly I think it helps telling stories around data, and what can be useful for.

item.title: Romain Lacombe on Using Open Data to Drive Economic Development
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Romain Lacombeis Head of Innovation for the French Government Open Data Task Force, known as Etalab. Through his work with Etalab, Romain and his team developed data.gouv.fr, the french open data platform.

In this HowCast, you will learn:

  • How Etalab implemented their platform
  • How they generated demand for these datasets
  • How Romain & his team designed a start-up challenge to illustrate innovative uses for the newly released data

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about Frances Open Data platform:
    • France's Open Data platform: http://www.data.gouv.fr/
    • Etalab: http://www.etalab.gouv.fr/
  • Explore the Gov Lab Academy Toolkit on Open Data
  • View the Open Government Partnership Webinar on Strengthening the Demand for and Use of Open Data Initiatives, featuring Jennifer Shkabatur from the World Bank andJay Bhalla of Code 4 Kenya.
  • Learn about diverse uses for open data in the Center for Data Innovation's"100 Data Innovations"report.

Transcript:

Building a National Open Data Platform.I work for the French government in the task force called Etalab, which is the Open Government Data Task Force for the French Prime Minister, and were building data.gov.fr, which is a national open data platform for France. So right after we launched data.gov.fr, the project got a lot of interest from citizens, from innovators, and the whole idea of open data is to make sure that the data assets that the state collects are actually made useful for everyone. So the whole question was how do we make sure that the work weve done, building this platform, gathering the governments data sets, making it open and publicly available, actually leads to changes in peoples lives?

Identifying the Need.In order for that to happen we needed it to encourage the development of services and applications. We needed to encourage a better informed public debate, thanks to data journalism, thanks to data visualizations, thanks to all these developments that can be built on open data. And the main factor that brings this sort of development back is usually the fact that those innovators need to have an audience. They need to have resources. They need to be able to reach the broader public. As the government, were in a very privileged position to connect all these actors, to really become a platform of sorts where we bring in those young, up-and-coming developers. We bring in designers, we bring those innovators together, and we make them more well-known to the general public to bring those connections together.

Designing a Startup Challenge.So far weve had three rounds of this startup challenge. This contest has led to about 20 startups being recognized as specifically innovative. To bring this sort of initiatives forward, there are many dimensions in which we can make a bigger impact on peoples lives by partnering with innovators. The first obvious thing is we need to release more data, because the more tools innovators have at their disposal, the better equipped they will be in order to develop those new services. The other thing is, of course, weve been talking to the entire French community, but theres a bias in the sense that people that follow what we do have been able to apply to this contest. So we now want to partner with all the major cities throughout France, beyond Paris and beyond the usual communities that weve been able to bring together at our meetups and our events, so that local innovation also gets recognized by this contest. And the third point, something that were very happy about, this fourth edition of Data Connections thats going on right now, is for the first time open to projects worldwide as long as the product is available in French. So its a way to encourage innovation wherever it happens in the world, as long as it is data-driven, and as long as it is useful for the French-speaking audiences that we try to empower through open data and the power of open.

Key to Sustainability.The key to make this project sustainable is for innovators to be able to bring new ideas to the drawing board and to build new services. And that happens only if the government and all its agencies are able to make more data sets available. We launched the Open Data Initiative in France in 2011. We now have a very good track record of working with all the different agencies and departments. Theres a massive amount of data thats being made available. But so far we still are falling short in terms of having access to the best quality real-time data from the larger systems in our environment. So theres a tremendous opportunity here to make government more modern, more open, more transparent and much more effective in the way we deliver public services.

The Power of Open.I think that the tremendous developments in technology that weve seen over the past few years have radically changed the amount of transparency that can go into the system. As in every industrial nation we face challenges linked to the transformation of our populations; we face really key questions about what should be our role in the world and how should public policies adapt to these changes. What makes me very hopeful is the fact that thanks to much better access to data, much better tools to inform the public about those problems and these challenges, I think we can come to much better solutions than what weve even imagined so far. That is what makes me hopeful. The power of open really lies in the hands of the citizens, and its about what we can do with that information. Its all about how can we change the world thanks to better access to data.

item.title: Blair Glencorse on Helping Communities Build Tools for Transparency
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Blair Glencorseis the Executive Director of the Accountability Lab, an independent non-profit that supports innovative and collaborative accountability tools and communities.

In this HowCast, you will learn:

  • How Accountability Lab approaches capacity building
  • How to balance long term change versus short-term results.

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about the Alfred & the Accountability Lab:
    • The Accountability Lab: http://www.accountabilitylab.org/
    • "Liberia's Daily Chalkboard Newspaper" -- Time Magazine.
    • "Alfred's Daily Press" -- Al Jazeera
    • "Innovating in Development through Accountrepreneurship" by Blair Glencorse
    • "Forbes Focus: First Shot in the War on Corruption"A feature story about the work of the Accountability Lab.

Transcript:

Incubating Creative Tools for Accountability.The Accountability Lab acts as an incubator for creative tools for accountability and what were doing is identifying what we called accountrepreneurs or people with creative entrepreneurial approaches to accountability and identifying them on the ground and the helping them catalyze and develop their ideas to make them sustainable and useful over time. I wanted to try and create an organization that could help them do, that that was really driven by the people who suffer from these issues not by external funding and not by external imperatives in a way that I think the aid system tends to be.That means beginning with listening actually just talking to people and saying, What do your problems tell us? What it is that its important to you? Then lets see if we can help you do that in a very objective equal way, not with us coming in with lots of money and helping do those projects but as an equal partnership.

Capacity-Building Resources.Id like to tell you about the projects in Liberia called the Daily Talk. Its run by an accountrepreneur that we found called Alfred Sirleaf and hes a citizen journalist. The work broadly in Liberia has been over a year of building trusts on the ground and building relationships and trying to understand who is doing good work and why. What are the motivations are? What they are really trying to achieve? How it fits with the idea of accountability and transparency? Id heard about Alfreds through talking to people, went to see him, built relationship with him over the course of six or seven months before we got to the point where he trusted us to work with him and we felt that this was something that we could take forward. Weve helped to connect him with small amounts of money but I think actually the financial resources were often the least valuable resources that we can bring and the lab focuses more on management, training, networking, coordinating with other stakeholders that might be interested in this kind of thing, in this instance the ministry of information. Weve developed a whole set of training modules on accountability and citizenship and personal responsibility and have some very good stuff on the ground in Liberia which is also took me a while to bring together and to make that team work.

For example, with helping Alfred in this case understand that he could do more with the basis that he built with the Daily Talk, that this is actually a great way to engage people in citizenship and in understanding their rights and responsibilities as citizens. Weve also given him training on management issues on the strategy issues: how do you build a project like this in a way that can make it sustainable on financing on that kind of thing? Also brought him into what we call accountability collectives which are monthly meetings of good people working on accountability projects in Liberia. Weve have Alfred and everyone else talking about what theyve achieved in the last month, in a way that updates us so we can take notes from that, but also allows them to see where the synergies lie and brainstorm on new ideas and collectively think about how they can change things in positive ways.

Long Term Change versus Short Term Results.I think taking time is always really important. I mentioned that we did try our best to really build relationships over time but I think often were in far too much of a hurry with some of the projects that we try to do and as a real emphasis on short term tangible results rather than longer term changing of mindsets and thinking in a way that might actually be more sustainable.

Part of what were trying to do in the lab is like I said really trying and find a way to over time change the sense of personal responsibility and move the question from not what do we need but what can we do to help people take personal agency and push for the change that they want to see rather than waiting for someone else to do it or expecting external donors to do it for them because frankly I dont think that works. Its not something that western countries could be doing or should be doing and it has to be a Liberian led process if he wants to be sustainable over time.

item.title: Howcast: Marija Novkovic on Leading Data-Driven Innovation Challenges
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Marija Novkovicis a project manager with the United Nations Development Program in Montenegro(UNDP-Montenegro). Marija and her team at UNDP-Montenegro facilitated a process called Open Ideas for Montenegro, a social innovation challenge that asked citizens to design a technology-based solution for a public problem.

In this HowCast, you will learn:

  • How Marija's team implemented the innovation challenge
  • The importance of getting citizen input
  • The value of their collaboration with government

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about the Open Ideas for Montenegro:
    • Open Ideas for Montenegro: http://otvoreneideje.me/
    • Be Responsible App: www.budiodgovoran.me
    • "Can a Mobile App Help You Be a Responsible Citizen" - UNDP Blog
  • Explore the Gov Lab Academy Module on Crowdsourcing Expertise and Prize Backed Challenges.
  • View the Open Government Partnership Webinar onStrengthening the Demand for and Use of Open Data Initiatives, featuring Jennifer Shkabatur from the World Bank andJay Bhalla of Code 4 Kenya.
  • Learn about diverse uses for open data in the Center for Data Innovation's "100 Data Innovations" report.

Transcript:

Getting Citizen Expertise.UNDP Montenegro ran a project. We called it Open Ideas for Montenegro. Emphasis on Open because it was an experiment in social innovation. We wanted to ask the citizens themselves to create a technology-based solution for problems they themselves see as most critical in their daily lives. We wanted to create a space for citizens to innovate and to create solutions for the problems they see when interacting with the public administration. The project ran in several phases. We had an initial consultation stage, which ran both online through social media mostly but also offline because we were conscious of the fact that not every citizen of Montenegro is using the internet. The purpose of our consultations was to ask the citizens, What bugs you when you are conversing with the public administration? We ran it on a simple concept: citizens are the greatest experts for the problems in their communities. Weve been hearing that over and over and weve been following other countries in their work in social innovation, and we wanted to experiment with it in the country.

Designing an Innovation Challenge.We did it in the form of a competition, but that was the kind of experience we wanted going on. The process involved two stages. The first stage was initial consultation, so getting information on what should be tackled, what are these problems where we would need to find a technology-based solution. The second stage was a competition for young software developers from the country to actually craft these technology-rooted solutions. We announced the rules back in March this year. We then gave them several weeks and mentors to work on their solutions. In May, we met for the final event where every participant presented their solution, and then we awarded two prizes. In the end, we had eight teams competing for the prizes and they involved more than 30 people. The winning team actually came from our faculty of electrical engineering. It was a mix of former students, current students and teachers. They called themselves the Creative Team of the faculty and they developed this mobile application that also is backed up by a web platform. The app works on a very simple principle: its capture and send. Youre walking along the street, you see a problem which bugs you, such as misuse of government-owned vehicles or tax evasion, traffic-related problems, illegal parking, illegal waste dump, you just take a picture and you send it through the app, through the web platform, and then its meant to create public pressure for the authorities to act, and thats actually what happened. Weve had anywhere between 100 and 200 civic reports for our category. They even established formal partnerships with the government Public Relations Bureau, which secured feedback for the civic reports, because feedback inevitably is very important for any kind of citizen engagement.

The Value of Co-Production with Government.What I really want to emphasize, what the biggest accomplishment of the project is: its the fact that it was adopted by the Ministry of Finance. The Ministry of Finance has to tackle the scourge of informal economy and they realized they needed many eyes on the ground to spot tax evaders. They decided to invest additional resources into the mobile app for us to scale it, and then it will be a main channel for reporting tax evasion. We did come a long way since November last year when we launched it until May when we formally closed the project, because in the end we couldnt get government on board because we couldnt explain the concept of social innovation to them. We couldnt answer their question, What will be the final result? It was a competition of people we did not know who would enter and we would not know which product they create. From that, from government not being on board, to government adopting the result as an integral part of the agreement, I think its a fantastic result for a really short period of time, proving the value of citizen participation, the value of collaboration and co-production. I can only hope that we can take it further, that we can replicate in other areas, that we can expand, that we can really work on reinventing the relationship between citizens and the government.

item.title: Felipe Heusser on Increasing Accountability Using Linked Data in Chile
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Felipe Heusseris the founder and CEO of Ciudadano Inteligente, a Latin American organization based in Santiago, Chile that advocates for transparency and open governance throughout the region through the use of technology and open data.

In this HowCast, you will learn:

  • The Motivations behind the Inspector of Interests
  • How the platform was designed
  • How platforms like Inspector of Interests can impact policy.

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about the Ciudadano Inteligente:www.ciudadanointeligente.org
  • Explore the Inspector de Intereses:www.inspectordeintereses.cl
  • Check out the Gov Lab Academy Toolkit on Linked Data.

Transcript:

Project Motivations.So the Inspector of Interest is one of the main projects of Ciudadano Inteligente. What it aims to do is unveil the potential conflicts of interest that may exist within congress between the assets and interests that members of congress have, and their duty they have to their legislative duties. We identified that members of congress have a duty because of freedom of information to disclose their assets and their interests. We actually went out and researched and gathered all the info, all the data, about what the members of congress said they had about their assets and about their interests, and we realized it was not that complete, So that's when we tried to get other public data sources, open data coming from sources like tax and revenue service, from the public register, and so forth, and we basically built an alternative database with what public data told us about assets and interest related to members of congress. We found that nearly 40% of members of congress were not fully disclosing all the assets and the interest they had.

User Experience.The Inspector of Interest is a tool that aims to exercise online accountability. So from a user perspective, users can go online to the Inspector of Interest, inspectordeintereses.cl, and they will find basically two main boxes. They will find on the one side, boxes or lists of members of congress. When they click one of those, it will immediately filter the areas of interest (agriculture, building, banking, so forth) that these members of congress have, and when they click one of those areas, they will see if there is any kind of bill, because if they voted or if they promoting that piece of legislation, and which they may have a conflict of interest given the assets and the interest they have. Of course, because we have lots more applications and all the data is crossed, we actually allow users to navigate and further do research to identify, not only potential conflicts of interest, but actually actual conflicts of interest. What technology is doing here, and what we're trying to do is basically easy the track about identifying potential conflict of interest, but that is the task of every user of the community.

Impact on Policy.It is about not having just shiny apps and applications that are just fun and are impressive, in terms of what they can do. These kind of tools, as any other tool in the open government or the government space is not complete unless it actually serves the policy purpose it was made for. So even if we can do this kind of thing, it is hugely important in the use of the platform is much more massive, so that we can actually exercise, identify, again, conflicts of interest, but then do the job that needs to be done later on, which sometimes may end in a change in legislation, in sanctions to those who are actually in corrupt activity. Because of some of the impact weve had already, there are many other countries that are trying to use this tool, and implement it and deploy it in their own contexts. So we are looking forward to working with them. In some cases we are already are working with them so the Inspector of Interests can serve other countries as well.

item.title: Lorenzo Delesques on Empowering Citizens to Monitor Development Projects
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Lorenzo Delesquesis the Founder of Integrity Watch Afghanistan, a civil society organization in Afghanistan with a mission of "increasing transparency, integrity and accountability in Afghanistan through the provision of policy-oriented research, development of training tools and facilitation of policy dialogue".

In this HowCast, you will learn:

  • How IWA started its community monitoring project, which facilitated the local oversight of aid projects
  • How they navigated the complex web of stakeholders to meet their goals

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about Integrity Watch Afghanistan:
  • Explore the Community-Based Monitoring Toolkit.
 

Transcript:

Starting a Community Monitoring Initiative.Im the founder of Integrity Watch Afghanistan. The organization is doing research and community-based monitoring, which helps beneficiaries to be more in the center of the aid and we developed a methodology that also makes sure that the citizens are actually a real actor of aid and reconstruction. The very initial thing was how to bring an elephant in the room so we started by speaking to the government, explaining them that we are going to do some monitoring as an NGO and they told us, Youre an NGO? You cannot touch monitoring. This is a state business. We told them, No, but you know, we are monitoring the aid and different things and this will help you to actually have information about what is happening around you. And they said, Okay. So then we went to meet different leaders and we gathered many people from the community, like 60, 70, 80 persons in a mosque and we explained them that look, you have a right as a beneficiary to ask information about this public good and this is how youre going to do it.The major problem that we faced was the fact that communities were actually witnessing problems on projects. For example, a school which was constructed by lets say the UN was facing some structural problems. The communities were actually witnessing them but they did not have any channels to actually voice these up. What we did is that we elected in the community people that were in charge of checking the quality of the aid projects that were chosen by the community and that were then followed by the people that were elected to do that. Once they were elected, they would be trained by our organization and they would then on a regular base, every week, go and check their public good that was contributed by that school or by the project that theyve chosen and once they started to check the projects, they took pictures, they took interviews with the workers and if there was a problem, they would just bring it up in a forum that was constituted of state people, of local monitors, of elected people in which the problem was discussed with tangible elements . This created precedence in the mind of the people, in their capacity to actually change things on actors that for them were actually, before that, unreachable.

Creating Tools to Empower Communities.In order to be more effective, we need a real close collaboration with the state, which we have. We sign documents of mutual responsibilities between the organization and the state. We need to have the people to be more autonomous in defining and actually reiterating the experience by themselves, without our help. For this, we created a website called communitymonitoring.org in which you find all the methodology in detail on how organize, how many times you have to go in the field to check, how do you do the election, how do you make sure that the elections are correct, videos to show engineering tests, basic engineering tests for people who are even illiterate could have access to these things so that they can organize by themselves.

Exerting Pressure and Shaping Development.We were able to actually fight corruption in infrastructure systems that were rebuilt by improving the quality of the project at least to the satisfaction of the communities. We exerted pressure to the organization, to the different donors, with the say of the people. So we were able to actually bring up the voices of people to get access to that information that was key for them in order to be able to monitor the project in a tangible manner. We did that process on 600 projects in the last five years and we can say that when we faced a problem, about 70% of the problem that were identified were actually solved through that process.

item.title: Francis Maude: Publishing Beneficial Ownership, UK
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Francis Maudeis the Minister for the Cabinet Office and Paymaster General of the United Kingdom.

In this HowCast, you will learn:

  • What beneficial ownership is and why it's important
  • How civil society used the OGP process to push the creation of an open, compulsory register of beneficial ownership in the UK
  • How this register has been perceived by stakeholders

Additional Resources:

  • Read more about the initiative: Francis Maude: Transparency must go beyond empty promises
  • Read UK Prime MinisterDavid Cameron's speech on plans to create a publicly accessible central registry of information on beneficial ownership.
  • Learn about an advocacy perspective on beneficial ownership: An interview with Rosie Sharpe,Senior Campaigner for Global Witness
Transcript:

Q: What is beneficial ownership and why is it important to track? A: The point about beneficial ownership is that you want to get a sense of, you want to be able to see who actually has the underlying economic interest in the company, in the business. The danger of not having that is that it can be used as a cloak of secrecy to hide assets and it can be a tool for tax evasion.

Q: How did the introduction of an open, compulsory beneficial ownership registry come about? A: Its obviously in the nature of the OGP that its a partnership not just between governments, but with civil society as well. So, the first action plan we did, we frankly didnt engage civil society properly and were criticized for that in the independent reporting mechanism. So we did engage properly, drawing up the second action plan. And the big ask from civil society was beneficial energy, a poll that registered beneficial ownership. Civil society was pushing at a door that was open so far as having a compulsory registry was concerned, theres a bit of an extra push to make it public. And we decided to go that extra mile, and its been well received.

Q: What lies ahead in beneficial ownership? A: We all need to legislate, to require this and that takes a bit of time. And wed like other countries to do the same. The greater the extent to which we do this in a really coordinated way, the more effective it will be. And you really want it to be done in pretty much the same way. It wont be perfect because we all have different systems of company ownership, company registration. So it wont be perfectly aligned. But you dont want there to be the option of kind of arbitrage between jurisdictions on this. So, a lot of coordination would be very desirable. And the sooner we get on with it the better.

Q: What will people look for the in data? A: What you might look for is in the public contracting field. Are there entities that are bidding for contracts under different names but with the same underlying beneficial ownership? Youll start to see some patterns, I think, across, international patterns. I think theres just, its very hard to predict what the uses will be. There will be loads of uses that no ones even thought of at the moment. And the great thing is get the data around and let people loosen it. Q: What are the potential benefits of an open beneficial ownership registry? A: Well, I think well see tax take rising. And a point that Camerons always made, which is absolutely spot on. That if you dont have a broad enough tax base, if youre not raising tax from a wide enough base, then you end up having tax raises that are too high. But, I think also, the other part of this which has been less analyzed is that there will be a mountain of data here. Theres enormous value to be had out of this. So I think were just beginning to see through a glass darkly, if you like, the beginnings of the possibilities that were unlocking here. Q: What has been the reaction to the announcement of an open beneficial ownership registry? A: Civil society organizations have been gratifyingly complementary about it. And, sometimes it sort of seems as if, well it cant be very difficult to do. Its quite a difficult thing to do, quite a brave thing to do. We are a very open economy. You know, we absolutely depend in Britain on being a place where people want to have companies invest. We need to be confident were not doing something that shoots ourselves in the foot. We think it will be fine and we think well benefit actually because it will make it a better place to invest because there will be more openness and stability. So, but, you know, its not without its risk. Q: What are your homes for open data in general? A: What I hope well see is an irreversible trend toward greater openness. People who open up and make data and other things transparent are doing something that is kind of quite rare with governments, which is to reduce their power. Knowledge and information is power. What were doing is taking it out of the hands of governments, out of the hands of bureaucracies and politicians, and putting it into the hands of people. And thats a difficult thing to do actually, but its incredibly powerful.

item.title: Arkka Dhiratara: LAPOR, Indonesia
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Arkka Dhiratarais the Associate Director of the President's Delivery Unit for Development Monitoring and Oversight in Indonesia.

In this video, you will learn:

  • The motivations behind LAPOR, the Indonesian national online complaint system.
  • How Arkka and his team have utilized SMS messaging, apps, web portals and social media to connect with citizens.
  • The goals for the future of the LAPOR platform.

Additional Resources:

  • Explore LAPOR via the web.
  • Learn more about Arkka and the Indonesian President's Delivery Unit for Development Monitoring and Oversight.

Transcript:

I work for Indonesian President's Unit for Monitoring and Oversight. I work as a lead developer of system. I have a responsibility to create a national system to be implemented in the whole institution, so we help to monitor all of the work of the ministries.Indonesia is a big government. We have 72 institutions, including ministries and agencies, but we also have 512 local autonomy governments, so we have a complex hierarchy of bureaucracy, so if common people want to send a complaint to the government, where does it go? Because every institution has their own responsibility and jurisdiction. So we created a system, a national complaint and aspiration-handling system that integrates with all of the institutions.

So we have 300,000 active user, and daily we have 3,000 reports per day.But in our office, we only have 30 people. And we cannot be everywhere to monitor all of those projects.So then I have an idea from Facebook. I believe that in using Facebook. When you post a photo in Facebook, you can tag your friend on that photo, so that for every interaction on that photo, everyone will be notified. This concept that we implemented in LAPOR!. We create a social media-based complaint mechanism.

We have SMS, 1708.We also have a website, lapor,ukp.go.id. We also have an mobile apps.So we have an admin that certifies all the reports and takes all the reports to the related institution,and if those institutions respond to the question from the people, people will get the respond from the SMS and email.

Because all of it is integrate in one system, we know exactly how many reports that we send to institutions. We know how they respond to reports. We know how fast they respond. We know the quality of response, andwe believe that if we deliver the complaints to the correct institution and monitor and be transparent, how the government responded to the question, it will give pressure to the government.

For example, there's a small village in the small foot in west of Indonesia, in Aceh. It is going to take four-hour flight Jakarta, the capital city in Indonesia. There's a single player that sent a single SMS to our system that telling there is a broken bridge that has not been repaired since 2004 tsunami. Then we delivered those report to the correct institution. It's the local government of Aceh. Then the local government of Aceh by only a few months, maybe two months, they have committed to the input, the planning to rebuild the bridge, so on the next year term of project, they rebuilt the bridge. This is the result with only a single player and a single SMS.

In the future of LAPOR! I want more engagement from the public. Right now, LAPOR! has a lot of report per daybut not most of them is delivered to institution because we had a standard.We need to know who is reporting, where, what, when, why.So we need to get the complete information that we can send to the institution. We need to give more information to the people, how the good how to give good input to government.You can imagine if there is more than one person send a good quality input to government, it will make a revolution. It will give a great input to the government to how they deliver what the people need.

item.title: Al Kags: Open Duka, Kenya
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Al Kagsis the Founder of the Open Institute in Kenya.

In this video, you will learn:

  • About Open Duka, an online platform which seeks to publish relational data in Kenya.
  • The benefit Open Duka seeks to bring to both Kenya and the region.

Additional Resources:

  • Explore the Open Duka platform.
  • Learn more about Al & the Open Institute.
  • Dig through the Kenya's Open Data portal, a collaboration between the Kenyan Government and the Open Institute.

Transcript:

I work for the Open Institute, which is based in Kenya, but working across Africa, and what we do is that we work with governments, civil society organizations, academicians and others to open up government to the citizens.After the Open Institute, we worked closely with the government of Kenya to set up the Kenya Open Data Initiative, which was an initiative that helped us to collect government data and make it public through OpenData.go.ke.

Every time in our country where there has been a bit of a scandal the public always wonders, "What is the connection between the various people who are involved in this? How is it that you find a scandal, but no one is found responsible at the end of it? We started trying to figure out who is connected to whom and which companies are owned by whom.

Open Duka is a platform that we have built at the Open Institutethat is meant to publish relational data.Including whether they want to start a business, have a piece of land, or find a partner, they should be able to basically see how different people are relating to each other, and whether they are directors of which company, and that sort of thing.Open Duka is spelled Open D-U-K-A .org. What "Duka" means in Swahili is, actually, it's a shop.We want, through Open Duka, to enable people to make connections between people, issues, companies, public organizations and that sort of thing.The motivation for us is just to put the citizen in a place where they can be able to drive knowledge. They can be able to take all of this information that has been digested for them, and make decisions in an informed fashion.

Without Open Duka you would need to work very, very hard to find information that helps you to make decisions relating to companies, and also you have to work really hard to figure out relationships that have an impact on the integrity of a country.We are gathering all of the data from the registrar of companiesso that then we'll be able to know that Al Kagsis a director of this company, and this company and this company.His brother is also a director of that company, but he is also the commissioner for lands, or he is a public official in this office. They both went to school with Judge "So-and-so."

For us, Open Duka is a tool for integrity, but it's also a tool for development. It enables for the citizen to be able to make relationships about the things that they are reading about in the newspaper but they do not quite understand. Therefore, it enables us to build on the integrity of a country by helping the citizen to be empowered with this information. In 5 years, what we are really hoping is that we have Open Duka Uganda, Tanzania, Nigeria.All of a sudden, what that does is it enables a Kenyan to buy land in Nigeria, to open a business in Ghana, foraGuinean to open a business in Angola, and South Africa, and so on. Bydoing so, we can see great potential in terms of just impacting on the bottom line, which is economic improvement, socialimprovement for the people, and even political stability across the continent. I get up every morning and I go to work at the Open Institute because of the fact that I truly believe that if we just become open with each other, if we just become open at government, and civil society, and so on level, we're going to achieve a certain level of trust with each other. If you don't know what government is doing, then you don't know what they're doing wrong.But I think it goes all ways. If you don't know what I am doing as a civil society organization, If you don't know what I am doing as a school, or as a business, then you will never know what I am doing wrong, and therefore, you will never know how to add value.Knowing where people are going wrong is so crucial in terms of helping us to eliminate poverty in the shortest time possible.

item.title: Richard Bon Moya: eTAILS, Philippines
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Richard Bon Moyais the Undersecretary - CIO of the Philippine Department of Budget and Management

In this video, you will learn...

  • The motivations behind the Philippine government's online portal, eTAILS, which publishes financial data.
  • How Undersecretary Moya and his counterparts have used social media to further allow citizens to engage with the data.

Additional Resources:

  • Explore the eTAILS portal for the Philippine Government's Priority Development Assistance Fund.
  • Learn more about the Undersecretary Richard Bon Moya & theDepartment of Budget and Management.

Transcript:

I'm Under Secretary Richard Moya, from The Department of Budget and Management. I'm the CIO, and later on the transparency initiatives activities were attached to my office.The office was created precisely to push some innovations into the bureaucracy.

There is a general clamor for good governance.So that's really the driving force for all of this open data. In some countries it's efficiency. And we recognize that open data has benefits in efficiency. But in our particular case, the real benefit we're looking for is good governance first. In the Philippines part of it is really as a reaction to corruption in the country,specifically data on public expenditure is the initial main driver of open data.And since we're in the Department of Budget and Management, and since we're handling all IT initiatives anyway and we kind of exert some influence in some of the agencies, we said why don't we start publishing financial data.

The project name is Electronic Transparency and Accountability Initiatives For a Lump Sum. Now let me explain lump sum. The way we budget it we have line items in all the budget. But there's a portion of the budget where it's really just lump sum. These are the Priority Development Assistance Fund, which is really congressional initiatives. These are items that the legislatures would want the government to fund, so that's a lump sum. Another lump sum would be the calamity fund, because you wouldn't knowwhen and how you would use that so, lump sum.

For the longest time these budgetary items are just lumped, and there's no transparency on how these are spent. Particularly interesting are how the legislators spend allocated earmarked amounts to them. And there was this notion that some of the legislators are less than judicious in the use of these funds. And there were some rumors that some of them actually benefit from this fund other than the constituents. we said why don't we start publishing financial data, for the purpose of making budgeting and financial transactions transparent.

The Electronic Transparency Initiatives for Lump Sum is a online portal that allows the public to see how people are spending lump sums in the budget.The project is really meant to expose budgetary information to the public, something that was not available to them before. That data includes the legislator in a district, the projects that he identified as part of his expenditure, and the amount of money that was spent, and the date and the time that this was released and approved.So what we did was simply port that data over to the web initially. And then we progressed to formatting that data to something that's easier for people to understand. After a year we said, it's not enough that we publish this data; we want to hear what people want to say. So now in our website, in PDAF.dbm.gov.ph, we actually ask citizens to take photos or say something about what their legislators are claiming to be spending on. And if you allow them to take photos and upload it, effectively you've increased your auditors to almost all of the population. Nine out of every ten have Facebook accounts.So now there's that feature just recently launched feature that they comment on it in Facebook. It's a very cheap medium to allow us to do audit of public transactions. If you are doing something new with an old structure, you can't expect that new thing to happen very quickly. Part of the learning of putting it up is to actually create the institutions that not just will build it, which is actually the easier part. The harder part is creating a structure to sustain it, that data is actually given properly, at the right time, with the right formats.first there was disbelief that we were actually publishing the data. And then there was some cynicism that it was actually real data. And then they realized that this government was really honest inwhat they purported to do, which was good governance. For the first time there was complete digital disclosure of very sensitive public expenditure. there were three general consumers. The first one was the press, which had a hey-day just researching on all the expenditure. The civil society which finally said this is what we have been fighting for, now that it's here we want to take it a bit further. And the general populous, which actually helped us. When the rumor starts to come in it's hard to squelch that rumor, and the best way to do that is actual, factual data. So now, they can go on-line and find that information there and verify it.It's really initially just transparency, not even accountability. Let's just publish it. You know there's this story of Pandora's Box, when you open it, you can't put it back. I think that's what happened to us. We started disclosing this sensitive financial information online, which lead to a greater demand for other things to now be disclosed.Whoever will come next, because it's a political cycle, I think the citizenry would always be now requiring and expecting the same amount of transparency to whoever will be appointed. You know I've been in government for two years, five months. Prior to that I was a private taxpayer, and I felt that as a private taxpayer, there should be a way for me to know where my taxes are being paid. And it's very important to me because for two years and five months I was given that opportunity to make that happen.We were taught when we were growing up, you don't have to be rich and famous, you just have to make a difference. So this is making a difference in a tangible, real way.

item.title: Victoria Anderica: Open Government Standards, Spain
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Victoria Andericais a Legal Researcher and Campaigner with Access Info Europe

In this video, you will learn:

  • About the Open Government Standards project, which seeks to define the concept of open government and serve as a set of standards for open government policy.
  • Challenges implementing and enforcing an Access to Information Law.

Additional Resources:

  • Explore and participate in the Open Government Standard Project.
  • Learn more about Victoria & the work of Access Info Europe.

Transcript:

I work in Access InfoEurope. We havethe office in Madrid, andI'm a legal researcher and a campaigner.We promote transparency, and we have several campaigns in Spain, because Spain is the only country without an access to information law within Europe, and we do monitorings. We ask information to the government in orderto see if they're complying with the current legislation that are in Europe.We saw how, in other places, likethe United States, Latin America, Australia, New Zealand, new access to information lawwere being implemented, and they were really raising the standards. In Europe, no one was working on that. There was old laws from the '70s that were not actually talking about the concept of transparency that we want to reach in Europe. We do two things. On the one hand, we've been analyzing all access to information laws in the world. We have a project called the RTI Rating, the right to information rating.We run some indicators that have been created by usto measure the level of the laws in paper.The other part of the legal work is to try and help people to actually get the information. Many times, government are not complying with their transparency obligations, and we help those people who felt their right violated to actually defend that right and try to get the information.

We're working in a project called the Open Government Standards, and with that project, we're trying to bring together the different communities on civil society working in the different issues that forms open government. Access to information laws, without implementation, is like they didn't exist. We need people to ask information so that the concept of transparency becomes really exhaustive and complete.Because we saw how the different states were proposing in the action plans, things that onein its logic about open government wouldn't include in an open government policy.

In Malta, for example, they included the fact that they were going to cleanthe beaches so that everything is nicer, right? That's great, but that's not open government. In Spain, they said that we would be able to create a business in 24 hour. Great, but that's not open government. After that, we wanted to say, from the civil society, let's define the concept of open government. Let's give it a meaning so that government can follow some standards, and civil societyknow what to demand.

If the Open Government Standards were to be implemented in Spain, we could see how good transparency law would enable people to access information to, for example, how the public transport is functioning. If I'm going to get late to work and I see in my mobile phone that the metro, for example, is broken, I can take the bus. Things like that only happen when you open up the data and other people can reuse it.It's also important because the government, many time, they don't have the resources to be controlling every single access to information request. If we are there and help people to appeal in the cases where access to information has been violated, we can help the implementation also within the administration of the right ofaccess toinformation.

In the case of Spain, the country I come from, the situation now is not the best. We don't have an access to information law. Corruption is every day in the media, and, obviously, participation is not something that happens in the decision-making process.So my hope for Spain, the country I come from, is that, in afuture, we will have a transparency policy that wouldensure that people can access information.It would also enable people to be part of the decision-making process so that when a government makes a decision, it really adapt to its community. There is a big difference to take a decision about a kind of policy in a big city, or in a village.Obviously, I want to see accountability measures implemented so that Iknow that there is a really honest and public sector where the civil servants are really respondent to the public interest, and not to another private interest when taking decisions.

What I've learned after trying to implement transparency campaigns or the Open Government Standards is that it is a very frustrating process, but it is really worth it. We see the results. We've seen many countries opening up, thanks to the civil society forcing and making pressure to make that happen. The process is difficult, but the result is great.

item.title: Rafael Ariztia: Chile Atiende, Chile
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Rafael Ariztiais the Executive Coordinator for the Modernization of the State in Chile.

In this video, you will learn:

  • About Chile Atiende, an online network for government service delivery in Chile.
  • How this platform is meaningful to everyday citizens.
  • The lessons learned by the implementors of this project.

Additional Resources:

  • Explore the ChileAtiende.cl platform.
  • Learn more about Rafael & the projects of Chile's Unit of Modernization & Digital Government //Unidad de Modernizacin y Gobierno Digital.

Transcript:

I work in the government of Chile, in the administration of the presidency. My title, it's Executive Director for Modernization of the State. Primarily my focus and my role is to help institutions, parliament institutions, to coordinate themselves in order to improve how they deliver services to citizens.There is one particular product that we have put much of our focus. It's called ChileAtiende; it's Service Chile.It's basically making institutions collaborate in order to deliver services through a single network. If you're a citizen and you need a government service, you first have to discover which institution within government, and how and where can you get that. The role of ChileAtiende is to be the network for service delivery. A person who lives in Putre. Putre is a town in the north of Chile,so it's in the mountains.If one person in Putre needed to get a voucher for medical attention, they have to go to Arica. It's a port in the sea. It's a 24-hour journey.Today, this services that we're delivering in Arica, now are delivered also in Putre through the same existing infrastructure, the same existing network that already existed. But what we did, is we did coordination between agencies and we created a single brand for government services.And to that network, we added services from other institutions. Today there are more than 25 institutions delivering over 150 different products through into single network, that is a multi-channel network: offices, data platform and telephone. For a citizen that lives in the countryside or a small town, it really makes a difference to have an office where they can do things right and close to their home and not to have to spend a day or two going to the main city of the region for some paperwork or some government stuff. It really changes people's lives in terms of saving them time. The one lesson that we get from creating ChileAtiende is that first, government really can be changed. There's a huge culture of status quo, of things don't change. At the end of the day it's something that needs leadership, needs to involve people, from the very top to the very bottom.If you align the people, and you have a short term focus in terms of delivering results, government can be changed.I think people will everyday ask more openness in terms of information, data, disclosure. So I expect my children in the future will want, will not have any doubt where interest of the government is where the interest of the politicians are. That should be open. When you do something that it changes how government relates with people and how people get the services, it really improves lives and there's so much that we can do on that front. So we have work forever in the future because there's so many different pieces that can be improved, and to see how the improvement is done, its very inspiring.

item.title: The GovLab Academy: A Community and Platform for Learning and Teaching Governance Innovations
item.dc:creator: erika
item.content:encoded: Press Release: Today the Governance Lab (The GovLab) launches The GovLab Academy at the Open Government Partnership Annual Meeting in London. Available at www.thegovlabacademy.org, the Academy is a free online community for those wanting to teach and learn how to solve public problems and improve lives using innovations in governance. A partnership between The GovLab at New York University and MIT Media Labs Online Learning Initiative, the site launching today offers curated videos, podcasts, readings and activities designed to enable the purpose driven learner to deepen his or her practical knowledge at her own pace.What do you think? The GovLab Academy is funded by a grant from the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation. The GovLab Academy addresses a growing need among policy makers at all levels city, federal and global to leverage advances in technology to govern differently, says Carol Coletta, Vice President of Community and National Initiatives at the Knight Foundation. By connecting the latest technological innovations to a community of willing mentors, the Academy has the potential to catalyze more experimentation in a sector that badly needs it. Initial topics include using data to improve policymaking and cover the role of big data, urban analytics, smart disclosure and open data in governance. A second track focuses on online engagement and includes practical strategies for using crowdsourcing to solicit ideas, organize distributed work and gather data. The site features both curated content drawn from a variety of sources and original interviews with innovators from government, civil society, the tech industry, the arts and academia talking about their work around the world implementing innovations in practice, what worked and what didnt, to improve real peoples lives. Beth Noveck, Founder and Director of The GovLab, describes its mission: The Academy is an experiment in peer production where every teacher is a learner and every learner a teacher. Consistent with The GovLabs commitment to measuring what works, we want to measure our success by the people contributing as well as consuming content. We invite everyone with ideas, stories, insights and practical wisdom to contribute to what we hope will be a thriving and diverse community for social change.

item.title: The Evolution of #Gov30: Training the 21st Century Public Problem Solver
item.dc:creator: beth
item.content:encoded:
Last week, we put out a call for applications to participate in theGov 3.0 online mentoring and learning program. With only a few days notice, we received over two hundred applications from officials in federal, state and local government, community activists and organizers, professors and students, consultants and CEOs. They all shared a passion for solving some of the most compelling public problems of our time, ranging from food security to mental health to climate change. They told us they were looking for help developing innovative solutions and wanted better methods and tools for tackling public interest problems more effectively.

In its original incarnation a decade ago, the Gov 3.0 course (known as Law, Tech and Democracy or the Law of E-Govt and E-Democ or Networked Governance!) was designed to teach non-engineers about how technology is transforming the way we govern. Law schools typically teach their students how to use the tools of lawsuits, legislation and contracts as tools for social change. If being a lawyer was about solving problems, we wanted to think about how the latest tech trends can be applied to tackle legal and social issues

The idea was to:

  • Blend insights from law, policy and technology to create more realistic and expeditious solutions to problems.

  • Offer an active learning environment working on stuff that matters.

  • Flip the classroom and offer content online and via video and audio, reserving in-person time for group collaboration.

Over the ensuing years weve started to focus less on general trends and more on how to develop effective solutions to specific problems. Project based learning works! (Check out whatSteve Zipkeshas accomplished at Manor New Tech High School) Students coming out of this program, for example, designed, built, ran and assessedPeer to Patentand a wide array ofprojects(dotank.nyls.edu), such as a kiosk to help indigent litigants navigate landlord tenant court and expert systems to make law more accessible to the layperson. The program rapidly transformed from a lecture course about technology and innovation to an active learning environment where we used technology combined with law, and other strategies in order to:

  • Design new platforms and policies to support their use.

  • Learn by doing, working in collaborative teams to design every aspect of real world projects, requiring mastery and integration of legal, financial, design, communications and tech skills. Inspired by the work ofKip Hodges at MIT(now Arizona State) (this is amust readby him on solving complex problems) andwhat it means to be a good lawyer, the goal was to learn by solving complex problems.

  • Demonstrate the kinds of innovations in governance we were studying by applying them to real world institutions. We knew wed have a better chance of getting institutions to collaborate if these were student-led projects.

Last semester, I taught a version of this class to students from the graduate schools of public policy (Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service), interactive design (Interactive Telecommunications Program) and engineering (Poly) at NYU. From them, I learned what has been the most valuable aspect of this program all along: Its not about solving specific problems as much as training effective problem solvers. We are committed to focusing on this objective and improving our training this term.

We have two goals:

To help problem solvers learn how to apply technology, legal, policy and other strategies to challenging public problems, and to help them develop the mindset and skillset for taking an innovative idea from concept to implementation.

It is not enough, for example, to study how open data can improve healthcare outcomes or how crowdsourcing can be applied to anti-crime efforts. Good ideas, by themselves, are worth little (see Albert Savoia on Pretotyping on the Gov 3.0 Syllabus) without the knowledge needed to turn them into implementable solutions in real world institutions. As we take the program online and attempt to make it available to more people, we are seeking to:

  • Afford everyone who participates an opportunity to work on stuff that matters to them. You come to the course with a topic about which you are passionate and a willingness to devote time to it, which may be far in excess of whatever credit hours are awarded.

  • Help people understand the problem as well as possible before developing a solution. The best approach may not be to build an app or a website, but fighting to change a law, designing a compelling visual, or combining different small pieces into a larger approach.

  • Teach a method for solving problems that combines Innovation Skills, Prototyping Skills and Presentation Skills. Innovation Skills include applying novel approaches to problems. Prototyping focuses on learning to embody and represent an idea visually. Presentation Skills focus on the ability to communicate an idea in a compelling manner. It will be a challenge to deliver this training effectively in a short time frame. Well say more about what we are planning and seek your feedback in our next post.

  • Get people to set their own goals for skills acquisition. One size doesnt need to fit all: Participants can customize what they would like to learn.

  • Invite a network of mentors with subject matter and skills expertise to coach participants at every stage, from developing ideas to devising solutions and mastering the skills to implement them. Effective problem solvers need help from those who are working in the field theyre interested in, whether its biofuels or prison reform. They need to know what else has been tried and whom they might partner with to be truly effective.

  • Connect people to each other by forging a network of like-minded peers dedicated to solving problems that matter. We incorporate Skills Sharing into the course under the theory that every student can be a teacher. With the group we are assembling this semester, thats never been more true.

Despite the fact that Ive taught versions of this course at law, communications, and design schools for a decade, it is still very much in permanent beta. This term will continue to be an experiment in two ways.

First, we will be trying ways to combine online and offline real time learning to create an active, vibrant and enriching environment for traditional and nontraditional learners. The online course complements the in-person version I teach at NYU. Its unique in that the online course is not a MOOC where people sit at home and watch videos of lectures. Its a real time, peer to peer learning environment where well try to connect (fingers crossed) people across a distance or in the same room to mentor, coach, cajole, encourage and support each others desires to become more effective problem solvers. View thefull syllabus.

Second, and most important, the goal of this term is to develop a v. 1.0 of the curriculum for training the 21st century problem solver and learn how to deliver it at scale. Ive been teaching long enough to know that the only real learning happens when students teach themselves and each other. All we can do is inspire and support them. With the generous support of theKnight Foundation, the hope is to form a Rebel Alliance: partnerships with organizations around the country whether universities, companies or governments who want to become part of a network offering their own training programs. We are happy to supply content and a platform to support those who want to give of their time, energy and talents to doing stuff that matters and who have the mindset and skillset to be effective. If you read the applications to Gov 3.0 that I had the privilege to see, you would be heartened and inspired by the number of dedicated, creative, interesting and passionate people who want to contribute to the life of their democracy. Our program is designed to help give them the chance to do so. For more on Gov 3.0, visit http://www.thegovlabacademy.org/gov30/ Or Follow along on Twitter at #gov30
