item.title: Roberta Solis Ribeiro: Access to Information Law, Brazil
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Roberta Solis Ribeirois the International Affairs Advisor for the Office of the Comptroller General (CGU) of Brazil.

In this video, you will learn:

  • How Brazil's Access to Information Law is being implemented throughout the country.
  • How the team at CGU created a system to facilitate timely information requests online

Additional Resources:

  • Explore Brazil's Access to Information portal.
  • Learn more about Roberta & the Office of the Comptroller General of Brazil.

Transcript:

I work at the Office of Comptroller General in Brazil which is the anti-corruption and internal control unit of Brazil,but it's also a ministry that's involved with open government, has been leading Brazil's participation in the creation of the Open Government Partnership. Part of the work we do is very much linked to public participation, to incentivizingcivil society, and citizens in general to make use of public information to improve public services, to monitor public expenditures and, overall, make us a better government. Most recently, the biggest open government initiative we have is the Access to Information Law.Brazil's Access to Information Law has the basic purpose of allowing citizens to exercise their right to have public information.Citizens, for example, can know if the teachers in their kids school has missed work, they can demand the government the information why the teacher has missed school. They candemand information from public hospitals as to why certain types of medicines are not available.It really is a detailed law on how to have access to information, the procedures, the timelines, the obligations of government and also sanctions for public officials that deny information or in any way jeopardize the process of citizen accessing information. The law is very recent. It was passed in 2011, entered into force in May 2012 and we had, basically, six months to prepare.During those six months we developed an online system for information request. That was a huge challenge, but one that really paid off. It's a system that's really helping us make this law effective. Requests are responded today, for example, in average of 12 days when the law grants us even 30 days for a request.Governments usually come from a culture of secrecy and it's difficult to get people to change their mindsets.The biggest challenge was to train public officials in each one of the government's agencies so they knew how to work under the law, howthey would have to respond to requests, and how they would proceed in this new environment, to really get them to understand the new culture of transparency in the government. The future now ...the next big greatbarrier that we still have to overcome is making sure that states and municipalities also effectively implement the law.We have plans now to work with the Secretariat for Social Communications in Brazil to prepare a nationwide campaign to raise awareness, to let people know that there is a law. You have the right. Thisis the procedure, so make sure you're using this new tool that you have at hand. Open government, and openness in general, can have a huge impact in people's lives.It's information about how schools are working, how hospitals are working and about public safety. I do this work because I believe it can really help my fellow country people, but also my government. I think we have a huge potential to be much better and I see that we're a new generation in government that is thinking of the potential that we have always heard about, that Brazil is the country of the future, but we want to be the future now.

item.title: Marija Novkovic: Open Ideas for Montenegro
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Marija Novkovicis a project manager with the United Nations Development Program in Montenegro(UNDP-Montenegro).

In this video, you will learn:

  • The motivations behind Open Ideas for Montenegro, a social innovation challenge that asked citizens to design a technology based solution for a public problem.
  • What UNDP-Montenegro achieved with this social innovation challenge.
  • How Montenegro's Ministry of Finance used the resulting app to target tax evasion.

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about the Open Ideas for Montenegro:
    • Open Ideas for Montenegro:http://otvoreneideje.me/
    • Be Responsible App: www.budiodgovoran.me
    • "Can a Mobile App Help You Be a Responsible Citizen"- UNDP Blog

Learn More:

  • Learn How Marija & her team implemented the Open Ideas for Montenegro social innovation challenge and the lessons they learned from this process.

View the How Cast >>

Transcript:

I work in United Nations Development Program in Montenegro.We ran a project there which we called Open Ideas for Montenegro.We wanted to ask the citizens themselves to create a technology-based solution for problems they themselves see as most critical in their daily lives.

Montenegro is a fairly small country. Our current census data tells us that around 50% of people are online and with access to internet, so theres the challenge in itself. Not everyone is keen to have governance done digitally.If we are talking about open government, first of all, we have to bring it to the practical level. The first stage was initial consultation, so getting information on what should be tackled, what are these problems where we would need to find a technology-based solution. The meetings with citizens were eye-opening and very, very humbling because we had our mouths full of open government and these aspirational statements, but all these people wanted were a way to deal with their everyday troubles: not having to deal with corruption in the health sector, knowing where to go to enforce their rights, knowing what happens to their complaints, or just getting the attention of the authorities for a problem in need of fixing.We had a long list of problems, which we then compiled into a broadly-defined challenge, Lets improve the interaction between people and their government.' The second stage was a competition for young software developers from the country to actually craft these technology-rooted solutions. In May, we met for the final event where every participant presented their solution, and then we awarded two prizes. Our jury panel really had a tough, tough job. The winning team actually came from our faculty of electrical engineering. It was a mix of former students, current students and teachers.They developed this mobile application that also is backed up by a web platform.The app works on a very simple principle: its capture and send.Either youre walking along the street, you see a problem which bugs you such as misuse of government-owned vehicles or tax evasion, traffic-related problems, illegal parking, illegal waste dump, you just take a picture and you send it through the app, to the web platform, and then its meant to create public pressure for the authorities to act. It really hit the spot, I have to say, in our country. In just over a months time, it already had more than 1,000 active users.I really want to emphasize what the biggest accomplishment of the project is: its the fact that it was adopted by the Ministry of Finance. The Ministry of Finance has to tackle the scourge of informal economy and they realized they needed many eyes on the ground to spot tax evaders. They decided to invest additional resources into the mobile app for us to scale it, and then it will be a main channel for reporting tax evasion. I think the foremost lesson that we can draw from this experience is the importance of feedback, the importance to actually hear the voice of the citizens and for them to realize that they are heard by their government. For me, thats the core of collaboration between people and the government, real, honest, two-way conversation. Thats my biggest takeaway from our process.I can only hope that we can take it further, that we can replicate in other areas, that we can expand, that we can really work on reinventing the relationship between citizens and the government.

item.title: Romain Lacombe: Etalab, France
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Romain Lacombeis Head of Innovation for the French Government Open Data Task Force, known asEtalab.

In this video, you will learn:

  • The story of Etalab, the French Open Data Task Force and the creator of the French Open Data Platform and the Data Connections Project.
  • How Romain and his team plan to build on this project in the future.

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about Frances Open Data platform:
    • France's Open Data platform:http://www.data.gouv.fr/
    • Etalab:http://www.etalab.gouv.fr/

Learn More:

  • Learn the process behind Etalab's work and the tools they used in their success.

View the How Cast >>

Transcript:

I work for the French government in the task force called Etalab. Our Task Force develops data.gov.fr, the French Open Data Platform that was released back in 2011 and we supply data to innovators that is released by governments and by the different departments.But it turns out we also need to build demand for data. If you want this data to be useful and be widely reused, you need to engage with innovators. So we have brought together the entire innovation ecosystem in France, ranging from investors, research institutions, educational institutions, all the way to the larger French and international corporations from Google to the French railway system, and media as well, to help us highlight startups that do wonderful things with the data we release. So this initiative is called Data Connections, and the goal is to connect data innovators to the resources they need in order to further their development. So right after we launched data.gov.fr, the project got a lot of interest. So the whole question was how do we make sure that the work was done, building this platform, gathering the governments data sets, making it open and publicly available, actually lead to changes in peoples lives? In order for that to happen we needed it to encourage the development of services and applications.And the entire idea behind Data Connections is that as the government, were in a very privileged position to connect all these actors, to really become a platform of sorts where we bring in those young, up-and-coming developers. We bring in designers, we bring those innovators together, and we make them more well-known to the general public to bring those connections together. So far weve had three rounds of this startup challenge.One of them that I really like is called Tranquilien and its a mobile application that has been built by a big data startup in France in partnership with the national railway company.So what they do is theyve developed this incredible mathematical model, where based on all sorts of different datasets and sources, they can tell how packed a specific train line will be at any time of the day, all throughout the broader Paris region. Not only this, but they can also adapt their data and their predications to changes they see on the ground, thanks to a crowdsourcing model where all the users of the app, which is now actually being pushed in railway stations through a whole advertisement campaign, can feed back data into the system.What were hoping is that these kinds of examples where science, technology, design, but also partnerships with the public sector, come together, and will generate a whole wave of innovation in France. To bring this sort of initiative forward, there are many dimensions in which we can make a big impact on peoples lives by partnering with innovators. The first obvious thing is we need to release more data, but so far we still are falling short in terms of having access to the best quality real-time data from the larger systems in our environment. There needs to be an even stronger partnership between governments and innovators, and thats what we want to work on. The other thing is that we now want to partner with all the major cities throughout France, beyond Paris and beyond the usual communities that weve been able to bring together at our meetups and events, so that local innovation also gets recognized by this contest.And the third point, something that were very happy about, is for the first time open to projects worldwide as well as the products. Its available in French. So its a way to encourage innovation wherever it happens in the world, as long as it is data-driven, and as long as it is useful for the French-speaking audiences that we try to empower through open data and the power of open. To a very large extent the world is becoming more open because of all the changes were witnessing. The question from a government standpoint is do you want to fight it or do you want to go along? Do you want to actually harness these forces and this tremendous power to the benefit of your citizens? And I think thats what we owe to our citizens. Its what we owe to the different stakeholders, and thats what open government is about, making sure you reinvent government in the age of openness.

item.title: Ania Caldern: National Digital Strategy, Mexico
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Ania Caldern is the General Director of National Digital Strategy Coordination for the Office of the President of Mexico.

In this video, you will learn:

  • About the work of the Office of the President of Mexico on National Digital Strategy.How Romain and his team plan to build on this project in the future.

Additional Resources:

  • Explore the "datatron":http://datos.gob.mx/

Learn More:

  • Learn the process behind Ania & her team's work and the tools they used in their success.

View the How Cast >>

Transcript:

I work at the Office of the President in Mexico. I work in the coordination of national digital strategy and I lead the area of digital innovation. Well we're very excited because we're creating the national policy on open data and we're really starting off thinking about how we can move open data very quickly from being a passive resource to become sort of actionable intelligence that can get us concrete results. I think there's a big challenge for us in bringing this to a local level where it can be closer to user needs. For people to actually realize that this is useful for them. Initially we've worked with the team of statisticians, data scientist policy makers, and designers to come up with what we call the "datatron". This is a specifically an open platform, it's an ad infinite randomized polling system that can help us understand what type of data users are more interested in, and in that way help us classify and prioritize the type of data that will be releasing and also designing mechanisms for this data to be used towards really specific causes that users are most interested in. It's been very interesting, because so far up to today the most solicited data set is information about congress. In second terms, what citizens are most interested in, is information on local government. We're trying to focus not only on releasing massive sets of data, but also on empowering communities, and identifying them to be able to work together to solve issues that can have a social impact or even economic growth. It's been an interesting process because it's been five days since we've launch this site, its datos.gov.mx. Already there's been discussions spurring around this, on specific media, blogs and channels. I think it's been really useful because it's starting a conversation around the national policy on open data in Mexico. It's raising expectation as well, which is great for us because he can also become an accountability mechanism for us to be able to implement. With this project, our hope is to get communities to make government more responsible to what they're looking for. Once you get right people involved passionate communities experts around different topics, all around data, you can have and create insights that beforehand couldnt have been possible. I think what inspires me about open data is that the possibilities are endless. I think we have great challenges to link data to specific problems, and we need to be more responsible about articulating those types of problems and the types of causes that we want to solve.Because of the data revolution that we're living today, I think the potential is hard to realize now what it would be. Coming from an open governance perspective, sharing this type of work internationally I think can really help to raise the bar in terms of where the uses can be most beneficial towards society.

item.title: Blair Glencorse: The Daily Talk, Liberia
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Blair Glencorseis the Executive Director of the Accountability Lab, an independent non-profit that supports innovative and collaborative accountability tools and communities.

In this video, you will learn:

  • The story behind Daily Talk, a project created by Alfred Sirleaf, one of the Accountability Lab's Accountreprenurs.
  • About the capacity building resources that the Accountability Lab provides to its accountreprenurs to help them achieve their goals.

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about the Alfred & the Accountability Lab:
    • The Accountability Lab: http://www.accountabilitylab.org/
    • "Liberia's Daily Chalkboard Newspaper" -- Time Magazine.
    • "Alfred's Daily Press" -- Al Jazeera
    • "Innovating in Development through Accountrepreneurship" by Blair Glencorse
    • "Forbes Focus: First Shot in the War on Corruption"A feature story about the work of the Accountability Lab.

Learn More:

  • Learn more about how the Accountability Lab assists Liberians in addressing public problems.

View the How Cast >>

Transcript:

I work in an organization called the Accountability Lab which I founded about a year and a half ago and Im the Executive Director. The Accountability Lab acts as an incubator for creative tools for accountabilities and what were doing is identifying what we call accountrepreneurs or people with creative entrepreneurial approaches to accountability and identifying them on the ground and then helping them catalyze and develop their ideas to make them sustainable and useful every time. I like to tell you about the project in Liberia called the Daily Talk. Its run by an accountrepreneur that we found called Alfred Sirleaf and hes a citizen journalist. During the war in Liberia there was no media. There was no way of getting information about what was happening. Alfred decided to set up a chalk billboard in an intersection in Monrovia, the capital city and curated news that he had on the radio and from people and disseminates it through this chalk billboard in a very little cost way in a language that people understood and with pictures for those that couldnt read. He was at a moment where he had no money at all. Hes been doing this essentially for free for 10 years.I wanted to try and create an organization that could help them do that that was really driven by the people who suffer from these issues. Weve helped him build at that billboard, build other billboards in other places around Monrovia and not only provide news to people on a daily basis but also civic education information about issues that they care about. Weve talked to hundreds of Liberians and asked them, What information do you actually want to know about what the government is doing and what it should do for you? Well put it up on a billboard in a way that you understand. We started with how to use traffic lights, which was one issue that people really cared about. There were lots of new traffic lights in Monrovia and there was no public sensitization campaign. No one knew how to use them. So we started with that. We moved on to road signs. Weve done how to register a business, how to get a passport, etc. Were now coordinating it with the government to make sure that its providing information that the citizens need and that the government wants to put out to help them. Weve crowdfunded money to do this which fits with our philosophy of involving lots of people in collective solutions rather than relying on large sources of external money. Weve had lots of the citizens coming to us and say, We love the Daily Talk. This is essential for us. We cant afford the 40 Liberian dollars or about 50 US cents to buy newspaper every day. So this is where we get information." Thats what participation is all about. Thats what helping people absorb information and discuss that information and think about how it affects their lives is all about. If thats something that we can help to happen, then I think thats fantastic. The passion behind the Accountability Lab is that too often I see people frustrated with the inability to get the information and services that they need from government.What were trying to do is change mindsets every time because I think ultimately thats in a way collectively that society can move towards more accountable decision making were making What were trying to do is change mindsets every time because I think ultimately thats in a way collectively that society can move towards more accountable decision making and move the question from not what do we need but what can we do to help people take personal agency and push for the change that they want to see rather than waiting for someone else to do it. For me being able to try and help that process happen is also hugely empowering. I think if Alfred was here he would say that that he wants the Daily Talk to grow as much as it can and help citizens in every possible way and the role for us as the lab is really to catalyze that if we can in a way that he wants and in a way thats useful. Thats the idea. Its an equal partnership with Librarians like Alfred who are creative, who are innovative and want to change that society. I hope that even a few years from now this would be something that will exist in its current form but also in other forms that that make it relevant and make it exciting and make it something that Liberians want to use and that helps change their lives in positive ways.

item.title: Joonas Pekkanen: Open Ministry, Finland
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Joonas Pekkanenis the Chairman ofAvoin Ministeri, or Open Ministry, a non-profit organization based in Helsinki, Finland which facilitates the crowdsourcing of legislation.

In this video, you will learn:

  • The story behind Open Ministry and the progress they've made on crowdcrafting legislation in Finland.

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more aboutAvoin Ministeri:http://avoinministerio.fi.
  • Open Ministry Blog (English):http://openministry.info

Learn More:

  • Learn more about Open Ministry.
  • Hear about the tools they used to implement this project.
  • Explore the code behind their platform.

View the How Cast >>

Transcript:

I founded the CSO called the Open Ministry, which is about crowdsourcing legislation and putting well-prepared law proposals in front of the parliament in Finland. In Finland there was a constitutional amendment in 2012 where now 50,000 or 1.2% of the voting population, if they support a proposal, the parliament has to process it in the same fashion as it does the government bills given to the parliament.When this was coming into force, that's when we set up this open ministry in order to make this new institution as powerful as possible. We've been involved in all the 5 initiatives so far that have reached the threshold and are going through parliament. The most crowdsourced efforts up to date has been the copyright reform proposal in Finland. In that case, we facilitated online collection and debate and coediting of the draft bill. Then we collected with the help of volunteer lawyers those ideas into about 20 page law proposal format. This initiative was suggested to us by political street artist called Sampsa who has been active in different locations around the world raising awareness to injustice. He asked for our help to collect the people together to consider the needs for reforming the copyright legislation. Mostly it was online of course. That's what makes Finish citizens initiative tool so powerful is that you dont need to collect the support on the streets on paper. You can actually have people go sign it online. During the 6 months, it's not that long for getting the 50,000 supporters. We got the first 10,000 or so quite quickly during the first week of the campaign. But after that, we basically flat-lined. It was quite frustrating at some points to get the attention to the campaign. We didnt give up. In the very last few days, we surpassed the 50,000 supporter threshold during the last 24 hours of the 6 month campaign so it was pretty close. Now what happens next is that these ideas and solutions and suggestions are taken into consideration when the civil servants preparing the draft law actually start writing out the new suggested draft bill. They will be, myself included, on the committee making sure that the suggestions coming from the people will be taken into consideration. The challenge is to get regular people who are not motivated by personal interest to get involved. The politicians and the civil servants preparing the law need to understand that it's not a representative sample of the population obviously because people chose to participate and people with their own interests of course were vocal about their needs and requirements for the law. The idea isn't always something that can be implemented but they always need to be addressed and it needs to be explained why certain things that rise from the participation conflict with other interests and have to be left out of the bill. Typically I would say that these initiatives dont pass as such that parliament can obviously vote them down or they can make a lot of changes into the proposals. The main impact is obviously raising awareness to the issues, raising the public discussion and getting the deliberation going in the public sphere. What's exciting will all these new tools and pilots that we have in places that they're the first baby steps in what we can transform democracy into. It doesnt have to be about just voting every 4 years or so. It could be about influencing daily on what kind of decisions are taking place and what we want our politicians to be deciding upon when they go to work the next day.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] Joonas Pekkanen, Founder and Chairman ofAvoin MinisteriFinland Open Ministry. […]

item.title: Felipe Huesser: Inspector de Intereses, Chile
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Felipe Heusseris the founder and CEO of Ciudadano Inteligente, a Latin American organization based in Santiago, Chile that advocates for transparency and open governance throughout the region through the use of technology and open data.

In this video, you will learn:

  • About the Inspector de Intereses, or the Inspector of Interests, a tool created by Ciudadano Inteligente which uses open data to highlight the connections between the private assets of legislators and the bills they pass.
  • The motivations behind the work of Ciudadano Inteligente.

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about the Ciudadano Inteligente:www.ciudadanointeligente.org
  • Explore the Inspector de Intereses:www.inspectordeintereses.cl

Learn More:

  • Learn more about how Felipe and Ciudadano Inteligente developed the Inspector de Intereses and the lessons they learned in this process.

View the How Cast >>

Transcript:

I work at Ciudadano Intelligente. We're a civic technology organization based in Santiago, Chile, but we work in Latin America, for the Caribbean, as well. Our goal is to develop technology to promote transparency. One of my favorite projects, it's called the Inspector of Interest. It aims to identify potential conflict of interest in the members of congress between their assets with the way they vote. Basically, the premise is about protecting democracy and we use open data and freedom of information to reveal those potential conflicts of interest. From a user perspective, users can go online to the Inspective Interest, inspectordeintereses.cl, and they will find basically two main boxes. They will find on the one side, boxes or lists of member of congress. When they click one of those, it will immediately filter the areas of interest, agriculture, building, that these members of congress have. When they click one of those areas, they will see if there is any kind of bill, because if they voted or if they promoting that piece of legislation, in which they may have a conflict of interest given the assets and the interest they have. We identified that members of congress have a duty because of freedom of information law to disclose their assets and their interests. Giving that thought, we actually went out and researched and gathered all the information, all the data about what the members of congress said they had about their assets and about their interests, and realized it was not that complete, but we didn't know exactly to what degree it was incomplete. So that's when we tried to get other public data sources, open data from the public register, and so forth, and we basically built an alternative database with what public data told about assets and interests related to members of congress. So then we had two pieces of information, what they told us they had, and what public data told us they had, and we were able to contrast, and we found that nearly 40% of members of congress were not fully disclosing all the assets and the interests hey had. Also because we had access to databases about the legislative of work, which means the bills they were discussing, how they vote about bills, so all that information then can be contrasted, as well, can be crossed with the interests one, and then we were able to say there was some areas where there are potential conflict of interest between assets and interests that members of congress have, and the way they're working. I'm not sure if I was surprised to find out that about 40% of members of parliament were not fully disclosing their assets, but now we can prove it, and that was a big difference. That was a stat figure that you can give to the press, for example, so that the point can be raised, so the point can be discussed. It is hugely important in the use of the platform is much more massive, so that we can actually identify, again, conflicts of interest, but then do the job that needs to be done later on, which sometimes may end in a change in legislation, in sanctions to those who are actually in corrupt activity. And also, part of the next future we're seeing, because some of the impact we have had already, there are many other countries that are trying to use this tool and implement and deploy it in their own context, so we're looking forward to work with them. In some cases, we already are working with them, so the Inspector of Interest may serve other countries as well. So I think what motivates me is democracy. We need to use transparency, we need to use citizen participation to make sure again that democracies serve the will of the many. So we need to understand the context where we work on. We need to understand that, in our case, for example, about just 20% of people access technology, and nevertheless, we develop technology. We understand it's just that 20%. We need to work with that 20% so that more people can access the web, but more importantly, we need to work with that 20% with a focused strategy to protect democracy. That's what we're up to, and again, there's no change in agendas. It's the same agenda about rights of people. It's the same agenda about democracy, and we're using the power of technology to embrace participation and to bring transparency up to a higher level that again can protect this democracy that we hold dear.

item.title: Lorenzo Delesques: Community Monitoring of Aid, Afghanistan
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Lorenzo Delesquesis the Founder of Integrity Watch Afghanistan, a civil society organization in Afghanistan with a mission of "increasing transparency, integrity and accountability in Afghanistan through the provision of policy-oriented research, development of training tools and facilitation of policy dialogue".

In this video, you will learn:

  • About the the work of Integrity Watch Afghanistan.
  • About a case in which IWA successfully empowered local community members with the tools to monitor development projects and impact their outcomes.

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about Integrity Watch Afghanistan:
  • Explore the Community-Based Monitoring Toolkit.

Learn More:

  • Learn more about how Lorenzo and IWA implemented the community monitoring toolkit and the lessons they learned in this process.

View the How Cast >>

Transcript:

Im Lorenzo Delesques and Im the founder of Integrity Watch Afghanistan, which is an Afghan NGO that was set up in 2006 and that has been working on community-based monitoring in particular of aid. Its about roads, schools, infrastructure in general, but it can be about services. The major problem that we faced was the fact that communities were actually witnessing problems on projects. The people were a bit left behind. They were the recipients but they were abstract. They didnt really have a voice. The methodology to do the monitoring was very clear. We had to gather evidence, objective evidence of wrongdoing. You need to get documents about what was supposed to be delivered. We started to do that work in Jalalabad which is a small city out of Kabul and in this city we started to recreate hope in people by the fact that they started to become active and they saw changes to direction in improving the way public services were delivered, the way donors or other agencies of the state were actually interacting with them and they started to regain a citizen position in the society, which was normally the objective of the reconstruction process but very few projects are actually trying to tackle that point in Afghanistan. We elected in the community people that were in charge of checking the quality of the aid projects that were chosen by the community. They took pictures. They took interviews with the workers. We were able to actually bring up the voices of people to get access to that information that was key for them in order to be able to monitor the project in a tangible manner. The process of what we do is that we identify a public good, you identify a way to create public pressure around that good that is tangible for the people and thats how you change things and thats where open data is interesting because its about the public good that you get the data. Its just not open information, thats not enough. If you add the people view on it, you add really something that is very solid and that can actually be a trigger of change, can influence politics. Its an open democracy that you create, that is alive. An example is a school that was built with bad bricks. People realized it, asked for the entrepreneur to change the bricks and it didnt happen but because we were there and the people had to trust the process that we have, they started to mobilize the village. The village made a sitting around the school and they said, You, the company, you cannot continue the job until you change the brick." So we had pictures. We had the documents that we had to get. We knew it was a UNICEF school at the point, at that moment. We knew there were insufficient quality of work. And the company got real pressure and they changed the brick. And now everyone is happy of that change. The company got credit, the people saw that they have power, and we solved a problem that otherwise would have never been detected. Yeah, so weve been monitoring 700 projects since 2007. Weve trained about 1,700 persons to do monitoring. Those project were considered to be the public good of more than 300,000 persons. We were able to actually fight corruption in infrastructure systems that were rebuilt by improving the quality of the project at least to the satisfaction of the communities. This created precedence in the mind of the people, in their capacity to actually change things on actors that for them were actually, before that, unreachable. My impression today that we are using 19th century tools of democracy. They are good but they are 19th century. What we need now is tools that will allow every person to actually interact and really be able to be like an ecosystem to generate better information, better governance to exert pressure where it is necessary. When I started I went to Afghanistan and I thought there that I would help. Actually, Afghanistan helped me because now it brings me new approach to be brought to the west and so now I would say that the third world is like a third way out of what we now have to improve our environment and Im really open to that and that were going to make it with open access to data, to information and with people at the center of that. So let's good for the third way.

item.title: Giorgi Kidiashvili: Opendata.ge, Georgia
item.dc:creator: Emily Thenhaus
item.content:encoded:
Giorgi Kidiashviliis the Director of Institute for Development of Freedom of Information (IDFI) in Georgia. In 2010, IDFI collaborated with the Open Society Georgia Foundation to create Georgias public information database, opendata.ge.

In this video, you will learn:

  • The story behind Georgia's Public Information Database, Opendata.ge.
  • How the publishing of government data led to real policy change in Georgia.

Additional Resources:

  • Learn more about opendata.ge:
    • Georgia Public Information Database: http://www.opendata.ge
    • IDFI Website: http://www.idfi.ge
    • Open Society Georgia Foundation: http://www.osgf.ge

Learn More:

  • Learn more about how Giorgi & IDFI implemented the Public Information Database and the lessons they learned in this process.

View the How Cast >>

Transcript:

I come from a Georgian organization. I work for is Institute for Development of Freedom of Information, shortly its IDFI. We mainly are focused on developing transparency, accountability of the government and promoting freedom of information, monitoring government institutions in their accountability. We also monitor the electronic transparency in Georgia. I would like to talk about the achievements in access to information in Georgia. The name of the project was Public Information Database, www.opendata.ge. The purpose of the project was to collect public information that was kept by the government. There was not a single website where government institution was published online. We requested information, received responses, scanned this information, created a special website called opendata.ge and made it accessible to the public online. The main topics that we covered were the administrative expenses such as salaries, bonuses of government officials, also expenses related to transport that government organizations used, phone expenses, projects that the government were provided. There are several main topics that are covered by the question that we are submitting to government institutions. We didnt plan to have any additional funding to develop the project. It was so successful because access to information was quite limited. As soon as we published this information there was a big reaction from the public. The most reaction was about the bonuses of ministries that we published. We requested information from all the ministries but just very few responded to this, but those who were responded got the worst reaction. We tried to explain to people that those who didnt responded, they have to hide something which is worse than this that these guys, the ministries Im talking and deputy ministers got the bonuses. This reaction was because this information was not open before. When you find out that minister has bonus which is more than 20 times than your pension, especially for the pensioners, it really not pleasant. This issue was not regulated when we started. As I said, the first reaction was from the society because they saw that ministers are getting a lot of money, more than they have in salaries. Salaries is one point and bonuses is another. Everybody saw that minister had a salary and thats it, but it turned out that they have bonuses which his higher than their salaries. We advocated for this issue that it should be regulated according to the needs of the ministers. We finally achieved it. Neither parliamentarians, neither ministries, are getting any bonuses. There was increase in their salaries but they dont get bonuses anymore. Salaries is the salary today. I think that the project was very successful because it led to the significant changes in legislation. Now, starting from 2013, government institutions are obliged to publish information. This is mostly the information that we were requesting from them. For the country like Georgia where we have the legacy of totalitarian past and secrecy, to have such openness is already a big achievement. When we started monitoring access to information in Georgia, the percentage of responses were only 40%. In three years it raised up to 95. We were given the word by the Prime Minister that there is nothing to hide from the government and we were even more open. Lets see how the next report will show.
